REVIEW: Jan 18 2009 	Disappointing stay	Having stayed at Essex house in Feb 08, we had no complaints and as members of Jumeirah loyalty card Sirius, we decided to book another stay for our NYC trip in December. However, this time we were very disappointed with the level of service during our stay. We arrived for check in at 6pm after a long journey only to be told our room wasn't ready. At 6PM!! No-one at check in wished us a 'welcome back', which we have come to expect from a Jumeirah hotel. We were given vouchers to order a house cocktail while we waited for our room but no apology or indication of how long our wait might be. When we were told, 10 minutes later, (before anyone had come to order our drink) that our room was ready, we went up only to find 3 staff members in the room scrubbing the carpet, and apologising that they were just "getting a stain out". Delightful. The mini bar had not been restocked and we were charged for the water that was half drunk inside the fridge despite being told it would not be put on our bill.Turn down service was offered the first night of our stay but mysterioiusly not for the other 4 nights we were there. Breakfast at the Southgate restaurant was a farce; up to 20 minutes wait time in a queue right by the lifts, causing lots of irritated people (both in the queue and people trying to get in and out of the lifts) No apology was ever made by the front of house ladies while we waited, they seemed about the least bothered American restaurant staff I have ever met. The management of the restaurant seemed to be disorganised bordering on chaotic, every morning we would stare at half a restaurant full of empty tables that needed clearing while we queued to eat. When they were cleared they were not restocked properly and we constantly had to ask for butter, jam, milk etc. The wait staff, although well meaning, were badly trained and inefficient. One morning once we finally did sit down we waited 10 minutes to be served juice and coffee and I ended up helping myself to juice and serving the 3 tables around me as well. Each morning our simple order of 1 espresso and a decaf coffee plus 2 toasted English muffins proved too much to handle and we didn't get the right order on first time of asking even once. Two shining lights of our stay were the Concierges - Cullen & a lady whose name I can't remember - both were excellent, polite and accommodated our requests with speed and efficiency. Aside from these two front of house staff, the rest appeared to be merely looking for extra handouts for doing nothing or providing what I would consider a basic service in a 4-5 star hotel. I have no problem tipping people who go the extra mile, but the bellman having me lift my own suitcase onto the trolley, giving me a ticket for storage and waiting for a tip? I don't think so. That was the general feeling I got from many of the staff - everyone wanting more money. How terribly un-5 star. Of course I put all this in a feedback form (the check out staff are not interested in the response to 'how was your stay' and merely tell you to respond to an email) but have had no contact from the management...I'm not suprised but I am disappointed. I'm unlikely to be going back to Essex House - there are plenty of other hotels in the same price range in great locations around Manhattan and in my opinion Jumeirah needs to do a serious review of their management to get service back up to scratch.

Dec 19 2008	Decent Location but........	This hotel has supposedly been recently renovated, but other than a flat screen TV and a motion activated lighting system that turned itself on and off randomly, there was little evidence of this. Our carpets were heavily stained. The bathroom has no vent/fan and steams up; there is an ever present mildew odor. The shower was useless and the plumbing has clearly not been touched in decades - in fact we were told at the gym that we should use the showers there as they were the best in the buidling. The door staff did not offer to help us carry our bags in. We waited for 20 minutes after calling to have our bags picked up as we were leaving and no one came. However, the beds were very comfortable.

Dec 11 2008 	very nice	we really enjoyed our short stay. room was beautiful and shower very nice. room was very large for new york standards. bell men very helpful and nice. had drinks and finger food in the little restaurant overlooking central park on main floor. the sausage sandwich was excellent with the best chips I have ever tasted. breakfast was also very nice, but the food and drinks are pretty expensive. (the south gate restaurant was worth the money, the food was really delicious) nice atmosphere, I would stay again. the lady who helped us at the front desk was also very patient and nice.

Dec 2 2008 	Great location and nice hotel	Stayed at the Essex House between 27 Nov - 1 Dec. This was a special treat for my boyfriends 30th. After a very swift and easy transit by cab from JFK we were checked straight in and told we had been upgraded from a Queen to a King room on the 9th floor. The room was impressive, very clean, modern and a decent size. The bed was amazing, very comfy and the bathroom was spotless with premium toiletries. Lots of fluffy white towels and high quality bathrobes and slippers. The room was great, we were impressed. We didn't use any of the hotel facilities but they seemed pricey. The breakfast was being charged at $40 which we personally couldn't justify when there are so many great diners close by (we liked 9th Avenue - good mix of bars and diners). Very impressed with housekeeping. Downturn every evening and towels and toiletries were replaced. Housekeeping would also deliver ice if you needed it and they delivered with a smile. My only experience of the conciergie was a little slow and there was a confusion over a birthday cake not being ordered but they did deliver a champagne bucket to our room as requested with chocolate covered strawberries which was a nice touch and complimentary. Great location and very handy for 5th Avenue, Times Square and Broadway etc and I would stay there again for sure.

Dec 1 2008 	Should be great......but the empolyee came into the room in the moring!!!	Actually, I just lived 6ix blocks from Jumeirah Essex House. . I got the room(Central Park Queen) from hotels.com, so my girl friend and I went to spend a night there on Thanksgiving(11/27) , and if it is good, then I will let my family to stay there when X'mas visiting. So, ok, we took it...so what is view from my luxury Central Park room? Next morning, around 9:30, when we was sleeping with our underwear, there was a black guy with employee's uniform came into our room..it was really scared us. He just gave us one bell ring then just open the door come in..We event still were on the bed without any consciousness. It is very unprofessional for a four or five stars rating hotel to have this kind of problem. And this time, it was the turn for my girl friend getting crazy, and I tried to calm her down.  When we checked out, of course, we told them what happened in the morning., but they looks like not a big problem..We were really upset...This is really a good hotel from the location and interior of building, but for the service...it is kind of horrible..maybe we are just unlucky!.

Nov 26 2008	The Essex House is Excellent!	I recently stayed here a couple of Saturdays ago in room 1130. I highly suggest anyone to request this room number as this King layout was quite large and when we were looking at another room of the same type this one was much larger than the "equivalent"Our experience from start to finish blew me away. I usually find fault in hotels and this hotel was absolutely perfect. The beds were beyond comfortable and the technology from the large plasmas to the LCD Touchscreen telephones kept me in awe. The rooms were very quiet if you had an interior view which can be quite valuable to anyone wishing to sleep at some point while in New York City. Everything in the room was of the highest quality. I have stayed at the St Regis and The Peninsula but due to the view(central park) and certain technological advancements I must say Jumeirah Essex House tops my list. For example, the robes were the plushest I have ever honestly seen in a bathroom along with the quality slippers with actual heavy duty rubber soles.The concierge was very helpful as well. My only complaint about this hotel was they do not have enough operators for the telephjones. Sometimes I'd wait for five minutes when I pressed "0".

Nov 21 2008 	Better off staying in a Tent.	If you are impressed by touch screen telephones, HD TV and movement sensitive lighting this hotel could be for you.However, if you expect any sort of service such as housekeeping (takes an hour), room service (too busy to take orders) or the concierge (maybe I needed to make an appointment, because they could only speak to me in one word answers) you are better off staying at a different hotel, hostel or tent. The service at this hotel is so poor that it is nonexistent. Your tired, you get off a plane, get to your luxury hotel ready to relax. Instead you stand in line, with a scrum of people in front of you, for at least 20 minutes to check in. At the Essex house you need patience as you have this delay at check-in, check out and every time your key stops working.For Room service you wait, and wait, and wait and then get put on hold. Perhaps take you own food supply. It is certainly much quicker to walk to a restaurant. I needed directions to get to a meeting. The only way I could this done was to go the un-manned business (then return to my room to get my credit card) and pay U$22. No way could they bring this to my room and in retrospect I probably couldn't have afforded this. The central park position was great but my room looked out over a parking lot.The rooms are a masterpiece of technology. The movement sensitive lights go on and off without explanation. Also beware of the hardwood surround on the divan. If you need the loo at night and cant get the lights to work you can really hurt your shins. Trust me I have the bruises !The breakfast at the hotel maybe good, I dont know. But It was nice of them to bill me for it even though it didnt go near restaurant or manage to get an order through to room service.If you want to know what it feels like to be mugged near cenrtral park, stay at the Essex house !At U$450 / night you can find better (at U$100 you could probably find better).

Nov 18 2008 	too much ton pay too little to get	i am visitting from london,u.k i have stayed from the 1st of nov till the the 14th of nov ,the room was big but dirty the sheets were not changed daily i had to ask to be changed, bathroom very dirty never clean toilets, the only thing they were doing is fixing the bed twice a day the bathtabe old daffintly i would not recommand it, for the price i paied and the length of stay i should get the best but unfortunatly i did not get and i am not a person that is fussy ,receptionist were nice and helpfull, breakfast expensive and bad, if you ask for room service they bring food cold.never to stay again

Nov 13 2008 	Grat Hotel. Food could be better	Excellent accomodations, really good attention at front desk and concierge very useful. Nov 11 2008 	Pass on the Essex House	We booked the Essex House through the American Express Platinum "Fine Hotels and Resorts" program. When I went to switch the water flow from the bathtub spout to the shower, the lever fell off into the tub. I reinserted it and got the shower to work and noticed that the shower head was rusted. Oct 27 2008 	5 star-Great Location	What a great hotel in an amazing location. If you are visiting NYC for the 1st time or the hundreth time this hotel is prime. You really get the feel of NYC with the horse carriages clicking down the street and the view of Central park. The rooms are small but clean, modern and great linens on the bed. The staff is friendly but you definitley get the feel you are in a posh hotel. Oct 26 2008	Cannot make my mind up about that one	I love New York and have stayed many times on Central Park South. Oct 24 2008 	Great hotel excellent service would stay again	I booked this hotel direct and found the reservations to be very helpful. The hotel is very expensive to stay at and if you are not from the US, you always have tax on top and then remember what ever you do, there are the tips to add. This was a special occasion for me, but well worth the money my wife and I spent staying there.The entrance is not large and overwhelming, it is discreet, there are more than enough staff on hand to assist you, if you are kept waiting they apologised straight away. We were taken to our room and shown around. We had a Manhattan king, which was been redecorated, it wasnt big and a bit tight and the bathroom small but it was very clean and every thing worked. The view was disappointing especially because they sell this in the description on their website, but then again what view in NY is good from a hotel room!If you have access to email, they had a nice touch of sending you an email address from the manager welcoming you and asked if there was anything they can help with to let them now. I responded and said that service was great and I was very happy although disappointed with the view because I look over a building site. Two days later I received a call offering a change of room. I didnt respond but they persisted in trying to contact me so I thought I would just be polite and take them up on their offer. We moved up to the 27th floor and were moved in to a Suite which was amazing! Please do not thing this is why I rate this as 5 stars, because the room upgrade was very nice, but the stars are earned through service, cleanliness and facilities.We used the gym, not big, but big enough, fresh towels, bottled water on hand, everything you need. Very nice showers and a nice changing area in the spa which you can use if you need to freshen up when you leave.A little tip, the hotel has two Merc's that will transport you FOC 10 blocks. They do get taken quite quickly so you may have to wait 5 - 10 minutes and its good to tip them a few dollars so it will cost you a bit like a cab, but you arrive in style!All in all, I would spend the money again and go back.

Oct 5 2008	Ultra-luxurious	I was part of a small group that stayed here for an art tour. The location couldn't be more perfect and the hotel has wonderful art deco ambiance. Sep 30 2008	Mixed Feelings	The location is excellent. Property is very nice since the refurb. Decor is contemporary and nicely done in my opinion. Staff is hit-and miss. Sep 23 2008	Great location not a great value	The hotel is very conveniently located with easy walking distance to the theater district, Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, the Museum of Modern Art and lots of restaurants. And, of course, it faces the south end of Central Park. I have stayed there twice, once before the renovation, and now after. Neither time did I feel that I was staying at a really classy hotel worth five hundred dollars a night. New York City is very expensive, but to get a decent view of the park one would have to pay even more than $500, and there are lesser priced hotels (e.g., Hilton) nearby with similar convenience in location. Also, despite the renovation, the bathroom remains small with a shower reminiscent of my college apartment. A few small points that were a little annoying- a conspicuous lipstick stain on a pillow, a nonfunctional telescope in my room that simply took up space- seemed to underscore that this place is just not up to the attentive detail of a really good hotel.The staff were friendly and pleasant.

Sep 18 2008	Great for Central Park	This was my first stay at the recently renovated Jumeirah Essex House. My room did not have a full park view but I was on a high floor and could just catch a view of the park from the corner of the room. The room was not large but adequate for New York and was modern and recently renovated.The fittings were modern and fucntional and interior styling was similar to the Jumeriah Carlton Towers in London. The great thing about this hotel is that it feels like a small boutique hotel despite its size. The breakfast was excellent and the hotel bar was also good.The Essex House is a building of historical interest and the hotel lobby has some great photos of New York thoughout its history and are well worth a few minutes to appreciate.The hotel has an excellent location facing Central Park and loans out free bicycles on a first come first serve basis which proved great for a sunday morning ride around central park.A great choice when in New York.

Sep 17 2008 	Modern Grandeur	Stayed for one night at the Essex House after my stay at the Marriot could not be extended and what a relief! Sep 7 2008 	Perched on the Park	4 night stay was marvellous. Fantastic room. Clean, very comfortable and modern. Service was good and staff were understanding of our minibar incompetence! Great hotel and bar, although expensive. Would stay again. Enjoy.

Sep 2 2008 	essex house - perfect location	We stayed at the Essex House on Central Park for nights, it was a perfect location to tour New York. Sep 1 2008 	Very good indeed	It is a very good hotel in a excellent location.The rooms are very nice and bigger than usual with all the things you need. Aug 30 2008 	I got a deal here	I put my father up at the Essex house when he came to visit. I booked about a month ahead and got a "Junior Suite" for about $400 a night on Hotels.com (They bulk buy bulk, we were told). The room was not a traditional suite with two rooms but it was most certainly as comfortable as any suite I have had.The service was truly impressive, world class hotel service for a room that was such a bargain. It made a huge difference in his stay, as he has some special needs that were handled with out a hitch.Other things are not a bargain, room service was quite good (and recommended) but expensive, and the hotel restaurant was OK but there are much better places in the neighborhood. My father has limited mobility so when he did not feel like going out the hotel restaurant was fine. But expect to pay about $150 to $200 per person for a dinner that can be had for half the price elsewhere.The area is very touristy, I prefer places away from the Central Park South to Times Square area, but this was such a deal and he wanted to be on CPS, for personal reasons.Finally, if the smell of horse manure is not something you want as part of your NYC experience, CPS is not the place to stay, nor dine al fresco. (Note: There is no smell of it in the hotel). However, if being across the street from Central Park is something you want (Like Jackie O, and other very rich new yorkers do) you get that here.

Aug 29 2008	Very comfortable hotel centrally located for all the sights of Manhatton.	Stayed for a long weekend at the Essex house hotel central park south. Very professional and welcoming staff. Handed chilled towels at check in to freshen up. Initially on 3rd floor but moved to 18th floor which had a spectacular view over central park. Room although small was adequate for two. Bed very comfortable and made up daily and turned down nightly. Lighting system operated by the touch pad on the telephone which was easy to fathom out. Floor lighting briliant idea when getting up in the dark and not such a problem as some are suggesting. Bathroom restocked twice a day with fresh towels and toiletries.Good facilities in the hotel. House keeping prompt and nothing too much trouble. Good security which was a bonus and the security staff presented in suits looked highly professional, cheerful and well mannered.Doorman remembered each guest and greeted with a nice welcome smile and cheerful banter.On day of check out our luggage was securely stored for our later departure and we were able to freshen up prior to leaving for the airport. A very comfortable relaxing stay and highly recommended for high quality and excellent service. Would definitely stay here again.

Aug 26 2008 	Very Disappointed	I read the reviews about this place but didn't really take them too seriously as I have stopped at this chain in both Dubai & London where I found the service second to none. However not so the case in New York. On arrival we were passed wet towels in a rather flippant manner, clearly as an after thought and just before we were heading to our room, which defeats their purpose. This seemed to symbolize our experience overall, lots of gestures which tick boxes but are without effect. The Essex suite was lovely and very comfortable however never cleaned properly. The turn-down service were unable to close both blinds for 4 days in a row, Ice was available but no complimentary water to go with it, Toiletries were not replenished and it goes on.I finally complained and again surface gestures were made for that day and then lack of service as usual. This is not what I expect from a 4/5 * hotel. A similar disappointment was the spa area the changing rooms had 6 lockers and only 2 showers.This hotel is all gloss and front with very little substance.I certainly did not feel that I was in a good hotel. In future I will take on board the reviews I read here as I have learnt the hard way.

Aug 24 2008 	Great Stay	We stayed at the Essex House for 5 nights during August. Got a good rate direct with their site a few months before staying . We registered for a reduced rate upgrade if available and were allocated a 6th floor Essex Suite on arrival. It was massive, A huge sitting room , Large bedroom ( larger than most hotel rooms), a good size bathroom and a walk in wardrobe. We were very close to the generator outside but it didnt disturb us we slept very well every night. The bed was a bit soft for my liking but was still very comfortable. There were 2 large flatscreen Tv's but we were too busy to use them. Alot of posters have mentioned the lighting. We had no problems with it except for the lights at floor level each side of the bed. All we did was put the spare pillows in front of them at night and no problem.We also enjoyed the hotel's bar, which although pricey, is a great place for a drink and seems to be getting very popular.Would recommend staying here.

Aug 17 2008 	A memorable stay	For our second trip to NYC we have chosen the Jumeirah given its unique blend of a historical building with a recent major renovation and its extraordinary view on the Central Park. We booked two special offers on the hotel website: the week-end package as well as the NY Waterfalls package. We arrived at 4:30 PM. Our room was not ready yet and the reception proposed another room or to come back after 6 PM to make sure our room will be ready. Given the proximity of the Central Park, we chose the second option and took advantage of making our first shoots at Central Park. Upon our return, we had the nice surprise to be upgraded to a suite on the 32nd floor. We found the Reception highly efficient with immediate attention given by four staff members of different origin to cater for the hotel's diverse customer profile.We had dinner at the recently opened hotel restaurant South Gate which looks cool and trendy. We appreciated the food, less the wines by glass, even so their $ 14 ++ entry price would let you expect some highlights. The Sauvignon first ordered had a strange and unpleasant taste, the Chardonnay suggested by the waitress as a replacement was acceptable.The suite was spacious with 4 windows allowing different photographic angles. The living was comfortable with a wall flat screen and office / make-up space and two windows. You will find one picture of the living with no backlit adjustment as to allow to appreciate the view on the Central park from inside the living.A nice king size bedroom had two other windows: one full Central Park view even from the bed and a view on the SE corner.The primary bathroom had a spacious shower cabin and a bathtub. There was a secondary bathroom we did not use.In general, the suite was immaculate and we really enjoyed our stay. The only downside was that there were a number of minibar charges without our opening the minibar and despite the fact that we immediately advised customer relations of this recurring phenomenon. Another highlight was the lounge with a highly design breakfast buffet area, a brilliant complement to the very classic hall fitted with old phone sets and outstanding B&W photography. Continental breakfast was included in our packages, but we found it very limited and decided on the $ 15 ++ upgrade to full American breakfast as to taste the vast variety of items on offer.The location of the Essex House is absolutely top: it is situated in the middle of Park Avenue South from where you find yourself immediately in the heart of the Central Park, the museum mile, the high end shopping, the Fifth Avenue, the Rockefeller Center, the Lincoln Center and Times Square. Overall, it was a memorable stay and we would recommend this hotel to any one that values its unique blend of features.

Aug 16 2008 	Great location but remarkable for excelling at nothing else	We booked a "high" floor room & were placed on the 5th floor which gives a view of nothing but tree-tops. High in New York means over the 10th floor to me. It is a fairly reasonable hotel for a major city, so what should one expect ? Nothing very bad, but nothing very nice was my feeling.A comfortable big bed, dated bathroom with crude plumbing, a large TV screen with modest picture quality, crude air-conditioning, hideous decoration, maddening lights which are not easily controlled, unreliable wi-fi etc.... Plus my worst, worst, worst feature in a hotel room - masses of small light sources all night - the phones, the light switches, permanent lights in the bathroom, loosely fitting window blinds and an inch of clear space under the door to the corridor. Oh dear....Nice doormen and desk staff downstairs.

Aug 4 2008 	outstanding	Cannot fault anything about this hotel. Perfect location opposite central park. Walking distance to the theatre and 5th ave. Lot's of small eateries in the same area with $5 delicious cheesecakes. Lot's of nice breakfast places in the area as well.Actually lot's of everything..it is NY after all. Great restaurants away from the crowds on the upper west side (all walking distance), on Columbus Av. Would definitely return.

And every time we brought the vouchers they had to go ask someone because they hadn't seen them before. A real hassle. There's no coffee making facilities in the room and we had a tough time finding glasses to drink water from. It was never hard to get a taxi anywhere because the doormen were very efficient. Always greeted with a smile everywhere you go. Sofa bed in junior suite was not comfortable because of the springs and we ended up putting in on the floor. I guess for almost $1000/night it just wasn't worth all the problems. Their price is reasonable for Manhattan, however, and if you have the money to spend on room service and extras, then stay here.

Jul 8 2008 	Quit luxurious and attentive staff what is there more to ask!!!	Stayed in the Jumeirah Essex House for one night in my way back home. Lighting, AC setting can all be set via the telephone near the bed. The room was really an oasis of quietness, the rooms we got were a twin double and King Essex rooms. Jul 6 2008 	Will not return to this hotel.	My partner and I stayed at this hotel after doing much research and comparison between this and similar hotels in NYC. We live on Long Island, and have stayed at several other highly rated NYC hotels, such as the Casablanca and Hilton hotels. We picked the Central Park King room based on the hotel website description stating that the Park view rooms offer "dramatic views of New Yorks famed Central Park" and "present exquisite views of Central Park, so be sure to reserve your lavish Park View Room." As we were celebrating our anniversary, decided to spend the extra $100 for the highly esteemed "Central Park View", and had requested a high floor.We arrived early 11:30 am at the hotel, and were told that our room was on the 5th floor, which was at the "tree line". We asked if there were any other rooms available on a higher floor, but was told that there were not. While the room was lovely and very clean and quiet, the air conditioning did not work well, and would not go below 67 degrees. The Central Park View which we had been promised ended up being a view of some very large trees, with no park view whatsoever (see my picture included with this review). With the telescope provided in the room, we could see the leaves on the tree. Not very exciting, and definitely not worth the extra money. If I wanted to look at trees, I could have done so elsewhere for a lot less money.We contacted the manager on duty to let her know that we were disappointed with our stay, but she made no attempt to compensate us whatsoever. In fact, she tried to blame us by saying that we had booked the room on the same day. While I can understand that there may not have been any other rooms available given our last minute booking, we still should have received what we thought we were paying for, and that was, according to their website, "lavish" and "exquisite" views of Central Park. In my opinion, if they are going to have rooms with a tree obstructed view of Central Park, they should list them on their website as "obstructed view rooms" or the like, so that the consumer is not mislead into expecting something better than a tree view. We won't be staying here again....for what we received in terms of a room with a bad view and faulty air conditioning, it was not worth what we paid for.

Jul 1 2008 	Very comfortable stay at the Essex House	I ended up at the Essex House through my firm's New York hotel roulette ("find me a room in Midtown," I believe I said). When I got into the cab at JFK and gave the address ("59th between 6th and 7th"), he said, "Oh, the Essex House or the New York Athletic Club?" Clearly this is a known hotel.When I arrived, the doorman opened the door of the cab and my suitcase disappeared with a bellman. As I waited on line (why is there a line at such a swank hotel?) someone approached with a cold washcloth on a plate so I could refresh myself.I had requested a hypoallergenic room as I'm allergic to feathers, and the front desk clerk sent someone to make sure it had been done (it hadn't). While I was waiting, I asked if someone could make a dinner reservation for me, and within ten seconds the concierge came over and made a reservation for me at some Italian restaurant on Seventh Avenue (good, but too expensive for the quality).I was taken upstairs to a city-view room on the 12th floor and while it was somewhat small (the armchair is oddly-placed), it was extremely comfortable. The lights came on automatically -- more on this later -- and I got ready for dinner.The toilet is odd -- it takes nearly twenty seconds between the time you push the lever to the time it actually, erm, flushes. The sink is one of those "bowl sitting on the counter" types, but the handles are in front -- if you have a small child, they can EASILY reach this and flood your bathroom. The shower was extremely comfortable -- two shower heads, good temperature and great water pressure especially for the twelfth floor, but oddly the drain stopper had been pulled out on its rubber lead, which lent an ugly touch to the bathroom. The towels are very, very heavy and warm, which is nice -- they wick away the water very quickly -- but they're stored above the shower and so they tend to get soaked if you use the moveable shower head. The porter had seen that I am not a 98-pound weakling and so replaced the house robe and slippers with something more appropriate for a tall guy.The bed -- I laid on the bed and went "aaaaaahhhhhhh, I'm never getting up, this is too nice!" Very soft and comfortable. The new pillows were just fine -- foam pillows are foam pillows -- but the hypoallergenic blanket was terrible. Brown and thin and stiff and scratchy like a camping blanket. Given that it had replaced a plush down comforter, I was not terribly happy, but that is what they had. It would take so little to have a small stash of comfortable, hypoallergenic comforters.When I went out, I asked for turndown for my return. When I returned the bed had been turned down, with a mint on the pillow and a heating plate of milk on the side table with cocoa mix to mix in. Very nice!When I got into the bed, I had a problem -- how do you turn off the lights? I mean, I've worked in IT for ten years and I've never had problems turning off lights in a hotel room. It took me nearly twenty minutes -- with me refusing to give in and just call -- to figure out that some of the lights are controlled at the front door, some of the lights are controlled at the side wall next to the bed, the purple (purple??) light above the headboard is controlled by a switch in the centre of the headboard, and the other lamps have individual controls. I still don't know how the lamp controls worked, because they appeared to be touch controls, but if you spun the dial, it would either turn off, or turn down. Trying to control anything from the room control system on the phones (three phones in a 20 m^2 room) was an exercise in futility -- you could see it blinking furiously as it transmitted data, and then nothing would happen for four minutes, and then all of a sudden after you had given up, you'd be plunged into darkness. The "moods" were useless as well. The most irritating thing, though, is something they trumpet on their website -- stumble lights. The bedside tables and the bathroom vanity have motion sensors and if you move past them, underlighting turns on and you CAN'T TURN IT OFF. Two minutes of non-motion have to go by and then it will turn off by itself. This sounds like a great idea, but let's say you turn over and the blanket falls slightly off the bed, or your arm dangles, all of a sudden it's BRIGHT in your room. If you're not the only one in the room and you get up to go have a slash, you'll wake everyone else up. I'd be OK with stumble lights in the bathroom but make it so I can turn them off!! Go back to regular light switches, PLEASE.Same with the room temperature. I never did figure that out. There was a thermostat on the wall that showed 22 C (that's, hm, 73 F or so), which is what I wanted it to be, but the phone control said the room was set for 25 C (77 F or so) which was too warm for me. I couldn't get the fan to run except if I used BOTH. Too confusing!!One nice piece of technology was that you don't have to open your door to put the "do not disturb" or "maid service please" sign out -- it is controlled by a switch right inside the front foor which lights up a red LED outside for "do not disturb" and a green LED outside for "maid service please". Your room also has a doorbell -- there is no knocking.The hotel has a car service for trips within a 10-block radius and they're fairly forgiving about what 10 blocks is (you will definitely want to use this if you've ever tried to hail a cab in the rain), or if the weather is fine you can use the hotel's bicycles. In addition they will lend you umbrellas. When I went to the gym on the 3rd floor to work out, a personal trainer helped me through my stretching, and explained that if I wanted (and for an additional price) I could have exercise equipment and a trainer brought to my room, or in-room yoga.Internet access is available -- both wired and 802.11g wireless -- but the wireless signal strength is not good on the fringes of the building. Access is EXTREMELY expensive -- on the order of $25 a day -- you could get a month's worth of access using your cell phone as a modem for the price of three days' Internet access.I didn't eat or drink anything in the hotel except tap water (New York has the best tap water in America, why should I pay for water?) and I had to call to request ice (it was delivered each day after that for me). I read about the $33 breakfast buffet and honestly, there's Petrossian across the street, and Le Pain Quotidien kitty-corner to that (both on 58th and Seventh Avenue), or on Sixth between 56th and 57th is an espresso bar called Zibetto that could have been torn straight out of Rome (no seats -- stand at the bar or get it to go, no soy no-foam latte half-caf nonsense, and cheaper prices than Fourbucks), or if you really want the New York experience, go to the cart on 58th and 6th and get a bacon, egg and cheese on a hard roll.In general, this was an excellent hotel and you'll be pampered -- if you can convince yourself to get out of bed. However, you will go crazy trying to control your room. Now that I've fought the battle (and won the skirmish with the stumble lights by blocking the bed table motion sensors with spare pillows), I'll be happy to return.

May 11 2008 	Could be so much better. . . . .	After a hiatus of several years, I returned to the Essex House ("Jumeirah") for a weekend stay recently. Feb 19 2008 	Fab hotel in a great location!	Jumeirah Essex House has a fab location overlooking Central Park. Its about 5 minutes away from 5th Avenue and from there its easy to get to everything else.We asked the hotel to arrange a pickup and when we finally come through immigration at JFK at about 1am we were pleased to have a friendly face waiting for us rather than finding a taxi. The staff on the front desk were friendly. Check-in was fuss-free and we were into our room in about 5 minutes from arriving.We had a lovely room on the 14 floor over looking Central Park. The room was average size, but clean and comfortable. Only disappointment was the lack of an oversized bath  unusual for Jumeirah. The bathroom on the whole was a little dated and not of the usual luxury standards that we have come to expect of Jumeirah. Nonetheless, the bathroom was clean and provided toiletries, lots of fluffy towels and bathrobes.The bed was very big and comfortable. The air-conditioning was a little dry, but every day ice was put in our room which we didnt use so just left the ice bucket open which helped put some moisture back into the air. The hotel is on a busy road, and you can hear the hum of the traffic. However, the disruption is minimal and more importantly the road was dead late at night so sleep was not disturbed.Breakfast was good, but maybe expensive if you had to pay for it. Luckily we had access to a free continental buffet breakfast as we are a loyalty card holder. That said, the quality of the food was good and ample  finding a decent buffet breakfast in a hotel is rare these days!The quality of the breakfast would lead me to believe that the room service would also be good. However, room service menu was limited and with so many places to eat in close proximity we didnt use this service.Staff in general were pleasant and willing to help. Much praise should go to a very helpful lady on the guest relations desk (whose name we didnt catch) who organised for my husband and I to use a room to shower and change in prior to catching our late flight, even though we had already checked out - we only asked to use the spa changing facilities!Overall this is a fantastic hotel. Despite some of the bad reviews on tripadvisor, we booked because it is a Jumeirah hotel. We were not disappointed and would highly recommend it. However, it is not a Jumeirah hotel in the Dubai sense. Its very much more face-less, has little charm (despite being beautifully decorated in the most part), and misses all the little touches that we have come to expect of Jumeirah. But you cant argue with location, a comfy bed, cleanliness and a decent breakfast!

Feb 9 2008 	very luxurious	My husband and I stayed here after an evening at the opera (this was the perfect location) and were happy with our room and the service. Feb 3 2008 	High style and quality at the Essex House NYC	I wanted to write about a recent stay at the Jumeirah Essex House, because I was so pleased it seemed to renew my love for old New York, high tea and Central Park.High tea is available in the lobby in the afternoon just have a seat and everything is brought to you, complete with scones, marmalades, tiny cucumber sandwiches, cookies, and of course a lovely tea service, this is open to the public. Jan 27 2008 	Excellent Essex	We enjoyed a great stay at the Jumeirah Essex House hotel in December to welcome in the new year.I must admit I was a little dubious after reading some earlier reviews but thought as we have stayed at the Jumeriah's sister hotels in Dubai (namely the Burj Al Arab Hotel) on several occasions and had never been disappointed that we would keep our reservations. This proved to be a great bonus as we could relax on an evening in our room with a drink & TV whilst our son had his own TV & privacy next door - great!Breakfast at $33 for the buffet was superb as you could basically have whatever you wanted and the quality of the food was first rate. Dec 23 2007 	Nice hotel but expected more...	Have been to NY 5 times before, we have always stayed near Times Square/Broadway. Nov 29 2007 	Celebration spoiled by staff	I reserved a Suite at the Essex House through Quikbook for our 25th wedding anniversary celebration for 5 nights and emailed the hotel several times warning them that we would be arriving from the UK in the early hours and that we would like to be on a high floor. Nov 20 2007 	Wonderful hotel 	We went to New York in October 2007, and decided to stay at a different hotel than we usually do. We chose the Essex House and was our stay fantastic! Nov 18 2007	some service issues but overall great hotel...	i stayed at JEH for 6 nights in early november. rate wasn't great...paid 679 for not even a parkview but november rates were through the roof at other hotels as well. this is my third visit to this hotel. frankly, with the remodel, drop-dead location on the park and friendly staffing, i don't want to stay anywhere else. i go to new york to hit the theatre heavily. and this hotel enables you to walk there for a comfortable 20 minute walk...nice to not have to battle to find a cab. the cabs are pretty busy on central park south. only issues i had with the hotel are that it is too high tech for it's own good. the tv mysteriously came on every hour in the night and i had great difficulty turning it off...i finally had to unplug it. the lighting in the room is tricky to figure out, the high tech phones were confusing and the calking was sloppily caked around the grout line of the tub and the toilet ran a lot. the engineer and plumber were called for the tv and toilet issues but they didn't succeed to fix it. I'm not a very picky person so by unplugging the tv at night and closing the door to the bathroom so i wouldn't hear the toilet running, i was o.k. with this slight annoyance. I didn't want to move my room at this point so never asked if this was an option. i did use the complimentary bike to ride through the park which was lovely and greatly enjoyed the restaurant...a beautiful little place to have breakfast and dinner...great food by the way. so all in all, once they figure out the problems mentioned above, the hotel will be perfect.

Nov 12 2007	No Essex girls here	I stayed at the Essex House in a wonderful room overlooking the park - it is definitely worth splashing out a bit extra for the view. Slightly reminiscent of Claridges in London. Sep 23 2007 	Suffering from a New York Hotel problem	Came to New York over Fashion Week, so prices were inflated beyond belief (just because there is a shortage of rooms in the city, does not give hoteliers the license to print money - there is such a thing as 'value for money' - no matter what the price tag...). We managed to get a good rate at the Jumeirah Essex House.I was keen to see the hotel, as it has seen an extensive refurbishment (close to completion) and as Jumeirah's first hotel in the USA, I was sure they wanted to make a splash.The hotel has a great location opposite Central Park. The lobby is very impressive (especially if you are an art deco fan). The disappointment comes away from the public areas. The room renovation is half baked. The new rooms are well laid out, but certainly nothing impressive. There are also touches, such as new sink and wallpaper in the bathroom, but old plumbing and showerhead. Hoteliers should distinguish between a full and soft refurbishment. They have also listened to the market's demands regarding technology and entertainment and installed over sized flat screen TV's - the problem is they are too big for the room. The phone also was a nightmare to use - very complex and with no instructions - impossible to use. One number for service in a hotel should be the standard.Not wanting to remain on the negative - there were some nice touches in the room. I liked the soft lighting in the bed headboard, good bed linen and also an easy to use alarm clock (Hotel Managers reading this - ditch the complicated clock/radio/CD).You can tell that the Unions have a strangle hold on the hotel. The staff were very much there to do a job and not to offer service to the guests. You constantly had to wait for elevators because they were full of staff (and contractors) going between guest floors. Customers did not seem the focus and you rarely saw any Management presence.One final point - the bathroom ammenities were over scented. Definately not right for male guests.I feel that the Essex House is reflective of probably most hotels in New York. You can tell that Accountants and The Unions have the upper hand. Most look tired, badly refurbished and lack any passion. I realise that money has to be made - but every price tag must reflect value at the end of the day...

Jun 4 2007 	Nicely Redone Rooms	This was my third stay at this property, the second stay since it became a Jumeirah owned property. A tub/shower combo doesn't really cut it these days--they should have installed a nice stand-up shower stall (a separate tub/shower wouldn't fit). The newly done lobby is nice, though check-in/out can take a while, given that there were only two desk clerks working. The bell staff was fantastic--courteous and quick. Housekeeping also did its job well. The gym is being redone, so they have a temporary facility in a conference room. It was serviceable, though nothing to write home about. It is a fantastic location for tourists in NYC for the first time and locals looking for a respite alike.

Feb 24 2007	A Wonderful Place to Be	After a very stressful time at work, I wanted to book a getaway where I could rest when I wanted to rest, eat great food and be entertained when I was bored. The suite is bigger than my first apartment. A good sized living area with a TV, sofa, chair, desk and under a cozy, a fax machine. The bedroom houses a king-sized bed and lots of furniture to store your clothes. Iron and ironing board live in the closet that I covet, complete with padded silk hangers, heavy wooden hangers and a safe.The decor is old-fashioned hotel luxurious. There are adoarable side tables, crystal bowls, a bar set with a silver ice bucket, tray and goblets. They stock the bathroom with Penhailigon toiletries, which smell yummy. Our view isn't all that great. We're on the north side of the building with windows facing west. We can see a small bit of Central Park, a decent portion of the west side and the entirety of a brick building that obstructs the view. It's pretty at night, with lots of twinkling lights.There are tons of people working here to make our stay pleasant. Everyone is friendly, saying hello and such. A call down to the consierge yielded a recommendation to the neighborhood pizza place, Bella Vita. Highly recommend the Za and the amazing canolli (leave the gun...) Sarabeth's, a block and a half down the street, is a great place for breakfast, a bit pricy, but the English muffins are delicious and a meal in themselves. Internet is available. They give you a choice of three speeds, with varying prices. We picked 512K for $7.95 per day and it's just fine for the small bit of computer stuff we want to do.The hotel has a car that will take you anywhere within a 10 block radius, although there's a subway stop at the south end of the park that's pretty good too.What really shocks me is how quiet it is up here on the 33rd floor. No street noise, no noise at all. There are only 6 rooms up here, so that probably has something to do with it. Yes, it's cold, but it's cold in Atlanta too. The deal is too good to pass up. We have a suite that usually goes for $1000 per night (or more!) and we got it for about $300 per night. It's outrageous by any standard and a miracle for New York.I recommend that you go to Duane Reade down the street for soda, snacks and whatnot since the minibar rates are painful. I mean, I might be living like a sultan, but I don't have the bankroll of one. My husband turned to me at dinner last night and said, "If you come across another deal like this again, take it." Word.

We didn't really use the hotel facilities as there is far too much going on in NY than to sit about in the hotel.I would very much recommend this hotel to anybody visiting NY, yes there are rennovations in progress but not to the point that it upsets your stay!

Nov 14 2006 	Lacked attention to detail other than how to charge	Whilst it has all the plush trappings of a de luxe property, the lack of attention to detail at the room level failed to give an overall good impression. Broken light fitting in the closet remained on the shelf in bits for the duration of our 3-night stay; the safe had been unplugged and I had to root about behind the furniture to reset it; the TV armoire would not close as the door was broken; the breakfast order form had already been used by another guest from another room and was never replaced for the duration of our stay. On the plus side the duty manager was very apologetic and made it up to us and the concierges, Ken and Christine, warrant a mention as they were extremely helpful with some complicated restaurant reservations, getting train times and organisation of other travel requirements. It was a shame that our first stay at the Essex House was marred by the lack of attention to detail. Interestingly, much is done to remind the guest that this is now a Jumeirah hotel, but many of the staff are still seen with their Westin branded name badges. Overall a tired hotel, but superbly located.

Nov 14 2006 	Marathon Runaround	In preparation of my participation in the New York marathon, our room had been reserved for over 8 months with the Essex House. It had been booked by our sporting agent who confirmed in writing that a park view room would be available for all marathon runners. When we arrived at midnight, we were directed to the 8th floor which was being renovated (plastic sheeting everywhere) and our room was located in the far corner of the hotel with grey, marked walls, dirty beige carpet and a small window looking out on to an office. We asked reception to move us and we agreed to vacate the room the following day. Of course, by this time, the 'all rooms are fully booked' excuse came up and our new room, although on the 16th floor, had the exact same poor decor and the view now looked out on to a brick wall. With the marathon looming and my patience limited, I decided to focus on the race. What a shame the hotel management could not have been more accommodating and welcoming to me after I'd travelled from the UK with the purpose of enjoying one of the best events that New York offers. One free breakfast was the only compensation made. I would have preferred a comfortable room with a view....afterall, it had been booked for 8 months.

Nov 10 2006 	Tired Overpriced and OLD Hotel - Avoid at all costs.	Given room as compensation for a speaking engagement in NYC for two nights, so I did not even pay for the room... That said, this is definitely one of the worst "high end" hotels in NYC I have ever stayed at, and I am a very frequent business and pleasure visitor to NYC.Although the lobby area is grand and ornate, the beauty of this hotel stops on the ground floor. Will not even go into the ongoing construction of apartments in this building and the very ugly exterior entrance.The hotel rooms look as though they have not been touch since the 60's or 70's (and to bolster that claim, just look to the 70's era touch tone phone in the bathroom and the 60's era dial phones in the floor lobby). Furrniture, fixtures and carpet are very shabby for a 4+ star hotel, especially one that was charging my hosts over $600 per night for the privilage. Room was extremely small - Very much felt like a typically "Holiday Inn" experience, but without ice or drink machines on any floor (you need to call for everything and they take forever).Although most of the the bell, housekeeping, door and security staff are very pleasant and helpful, this does not translate to the reception, conceirge or room service areas. Phone calls to reception took ages, everything from the drinks to the roqm service menu are terribly overpriced, even by NYC standards. Requested a pack of smokes for a guest to be delivered to the room from the gift shop ($8) and was told upon delivery the charge was $28 ! When I checked into the room and called the front desk to complain about the room condition and to ask if where was another room available, was on hold about 20+ mins, just for them to tell there was nothing they could do for me..

Oct 30 2006 	Couldn't ask for more	We had a very enjoyable weekend stay in NY at the Essex House on Central Park South. Staff was friendly and helpful. I was a little concerned about the renovations, however, did not notice anything inside (exterior had some scaffolding). Our room was 4th floor city view, but it was only $300/night on expedia, so it was great value. I imagine the higher floors with park views must be amazing. Comfy pillow top bed, only issue was with heat but we were able to solve that ourselves by just opening the window for a bit.Cannot ask for a better location. We went shopping to 5th ave (1.5 blocks), central park for walks (across street), MOMA (about 4 blocks), and, the dining within 1 block is amazing. per se is the ultimate dining experience, imho, for food, service, ambiance - and its only 1 block away in the time warner center. Rated #8 in the world for good reason. Alan Ducasse in the hotel is great too (top 40 in the US), but per se is on its own level. We got to visit the kitchen in per se, they even have a TV feed directly to the French Laundry (chef Keller runs both). Rue 57 (2 blocks away) is a nice lunch spot, about $15 for a salad.Not sure what changes are in store for next year with the new mgmt, but we really enjoyed our stay here!

Oct 30 2006 	Overpriced and overrated	I stayed here with a conference group in mid September and found it to be very average. Yes it is ornate and the entry is Grand etc but when I found out what the room cost was, over $1,000 per night (I didn't actually pay as it was part of the conference qualification) I nearly passed out. To say it is not worth half the money is no exaggeration. It was quite possibly the smallest hotel room I have ever been in to the point where the cupboard doors did not open fully as they hit against the bed! We also found the conceirge generally aloof and unhelpful and on the day of our departure there was a stuff up with all our luggage of mammoth proportions. Sorry but that is unacceptable from a supposed world class hotel. From here I moved to the Marriott Marquis after the conference and found it to be a far superior hotel at almost half the price. Would never stay here again.

Oct 11 2006 	Great Hotel...Even Better Location!!!	My wife and I stayed at the Jumeirah Essex House during the Thanksgiving long weekend (Columbus Day in the US). We are already planning our next trip back to NY and without question, we will be staying at the Essex House once again.From the moment we pulled up in our cab, there was someone there to take our bags, hold the door and after check-in, they were there to take you to your room. The staff was very courteous; everyone says 'hello' and asks how we were enjoying our stay. The concierge was a great resource and recommended some truly great dining.The room nice (standard room) and the bed despite being just a queen, was very comfortable. The bathroom was fabulous! The multiple shower heads made sure every morning started off right. I also enjoyed that they have a nice hair dryer, rather than those small ones you find at some hotels. The view was not great, so next time we'll pay the extra and get a park view room.The location of the hotel is ideal. 13 blocks from Times Square, 1 1/2 from 5th Avenue shopping, across the street from Central park, about 10 blocks from the Upper West side. The Subway is close by and getting a taxi is easy (and cheap).Great Hotel...Great Location...you won't be disapointed.

Oct 6 2006 	Great hotel stay!	What a great hotel in a stunning location We felt spoiled for three days. Only complaint is that there was a stain on the bedskirt. We plan on staying there on our future trips which are two to three times a year.

Oct 4 2006 	Essex House was a Good Place in DEC '05	My wife and I visited NYC for the first time ever last Christmas & New Years -2005. I insisted we stay in a hotel across from Central Park and that FACED Central Park.Essex house was one of the few and dwindling it seems. It is SPLIT into separate "hotels" sort of. One starts at the 26th or there-abouts floor and the former Essex House is below those floors.WARNING: BE SURE TO CHECK-IN EARLY AND ASK FOR A ROOM AT FLOOR 8 AND ABOVE !!!!!!!! Otherwise you'll have alot of street noise (it seems the cabs never stop honking) cause this can be a busy location on Central Park South. MORE IMPORTANTLY IS THE VIEW OF THE PARK !!!!!! YOU WANT TO BE ABOVE THE TREE-LINE.At that time, before Jumeria, it was reasonably priced, comparatively speaking, for a NYC hotel of that stature AND in that location. About $350-500/night. The new prices are MUCH higher now.The room was adequate and small (a QUEEN bed room with 2, 3 and 4 feet left around the bed, enough closet space and a large bath.), but we spent little time there.I mean really now!!!! It's NYC. We were out til ** 2AM ** OFTEN, sometimes just walking around TIMES SQUARE. Eating late meals at the DELI's.... Especially ARTIES on the Upper West Side.SO LOCATION IS IMPORTANT. Even though we were not at the room alot, I had enough time in it to appreciate the location across from and view of the Park. So it was worth the extra $$$ to me to have it. IMHOThe Staff was OK, the Bar was OK, The Door on 58th is locked too early. Cabs are plentiful in front. They accomodated our request for a higher floor the next day.IF the price had not changed I stay there this year too.

Sep 16 2006 	Wait for the completion of renovations....	The new owners are attempting to restore this classic hotel to its former glory; no doubt they will succeed, but it will take time. Sep 13 2006 	A Disappointing Stay	I stayed at the Essex House on the evening of September 11 after our corporate travel agent praised the property for its lavish rooms, wonderful views and great service. Sadly, my experience was very disappointing, especially given the price ($379) (and after enjoying wonderful stays at the Ritz and the Hilton in the past 10 days).I stayed in room 531 (spacious by NYC standards and clean) which looks directly into the windows of another room (so much for the view!) and boasts a bathroom with a broken sink fixture and rusty, mismatched shower fixtures. Overall the room looked shabby and very depressing.I ordered dinner from room service after coming back from business meetings at 10:30 in the evening and the food was good, arrived quickly and the presentation was great. The next morning I got up at 6:30 so that to get some breakfast before checking out at 8:30 only to find out that the room was missing the breakfast menu and that breakfast choices are not included in the in room dining brochure in the room. I called the room service (once) and a manager (3 times) between 6:45 AM and 7:45 AM pleading for a menu so that I can order to no avail. The menu arrived at 8:05 AM just before I headed down to check out. I must say that I have not gone through so much trouble in order to spend money in any other hotel. All the employees I spoke to about this unacceptable treatment apologized but it was obvious that they did not genuinely care about what happened. This afternoon I was contacted by the hotel with another apology (but no offer for any monetary or other compensation, in case you are wondering, which is fine with me since this was a business trip) and a request that I do not take the hotel off my list of hotels to stay in while in NYC. Given the choice of hotels in NYC, I simply see no reason to return!So, overall, I experienced a dumpy room and bad service in a reputedly good hotel. Based on my experience, I would recommend that people stay elsewhere (after all, New York is full of wonderful hotels) or if you choose to stay at the Essex House make sure before you arrive that you have a guaranteed room with a decent view and be prepared for unpredictable service.

Sep 10 2006	Average @ Essex House	Stayed at Essex House over labor day weekend. Got a decent rate on hotels.com. At their regular rate the stay would have been dissapointing. Pros...Staff (except bellmen) seemed to have an upbeat and welcoming professional feel, probably the Jumeirah influence. Room was clean, small, and unspectacular. King bed lower floor city facing. Hotel lobby areas and general appearance were meticulous.Cons...Bellman takes bags from us after taxi driver pulls them out of cab, follows us to the front desk and waits almost with hand out for a tip (two light roller bags), which I grudgingly give. It takes so long for the bags to arrive, my wife and a friend bring them up. This was poor form and lazy on their behalf. Room service was inconsistent sometimes room was cleaned well, other times non-existent.Since we weren't spending much time in the room it wasn't disspaointing, but it wasn't 4 star. I would hope that Jumeirah can impress their normally flawless service on the entire staff, so this hotel can eb restored to glory after years of starwood mediocrity. By the way I think management is doing a great job of keeping noisy renovations away from guests, it is obvious a major overhaul was ongoing from teh workers in and out, but we never heard a peep. This is impressive considering similar situations I have been in before.

Sep 9 2006	A great stay at the Essex House	We stayed at the Jumeirah Essex House for 4 nights from September 1st. The location is fabulous right across from Central Park and we were fortunate to have a park view on the 14th floor.We got a good deal through Quikbook of $228 a night and this was great value for this hotel. Rooms were a decent enough size and were very comfortable. The rooms are due to be renovated by Jumeirah and this is a good thing as they are starting to look a little tired for a hotel at the higher end of the market.The staff at the hotel were always very pleasant and accomodating and could not be faulted.I would stay here again but will probably never get such a good rate in the future.

Sep 9 2006 	Art Deco Splendour	Had a fantastic stay at The Essex. We had a lovely room with a view over the park on the 14th floor. The view is breathtaking and room was well appointed.
