Aug 30 2006 	Excellent Place!!	We stayed at The Essex House for a weekend recently and had a truly wonderful experience. The location was simply perfect, a few steps from Central Park and all the amenties of mid-town Manhattan. The room was comfortable and the hotel bar was a great place to relax. I highly recommend this hotel especially if you can get a good deal! For dinner - Rue 57 near the hotel is an excellent French Brasserie and the Brooklyn Dinner is a top place for breakfast/brunch.

Aug 30 2006 	Really nice hotel	I orginally booked an unknown hotel through Hotwire and was given the Barclay Intercontinental in NYC. 2 Days before I was due to arrive there I received an email from Hotwire to say they had overbooked us and were moving us to the Jumeirah Essex House. I checked it out on the website and it looked nice so I was pleased, especially since Howire were refunding 1 nights stay for us! When we arrived we were early, well before the check in time of 3pm, but they were very accomodating and let us check in to our room immediately. The room was very nice, clean and quiet. There was a nice bathroom and the bed was very confortable. Room was very big for NY standards. The rest of the hotel was being refurbished but you would never have known. I had the best nights sleep ever, and would definately return again.

Aug 11 2006	I miss it already!	My husband and I spent our 10th anniversay in NYC and what a great time we had! The Essex House was a very pleasent surprise! The location right across the street from Central Park and literally around the corner from 5th Avenue shopping was more than one couple could ask for. Yes, the hotel is undergoing some renovations but you would never know as we never heard any noise. Our room was very clean, nice sized, clean bathrooms, a/c and a view of the park! We felt as if we had our own doorman and were living in a Park Avenue aprtment! The staff was great and very friendly too. Only one complaint and really not a complaint: the bathroom vanity was on the small side but then everything is in NYC!**Terrific car service from JFK to our hotel: Pat's Lincoln Towncars 917-412-0544 ( the nicest New Yorker you will ever meet!)**Best CheeseCake: Carnegie Deli on 7th AvenueThanks Essex House and Trip Advisor! We will be back!

Aug 8 2006 	Nice Hotel	The Essex House is undergoing it's Jumeirah makeover and when complete I'm sure it will be one hell of a hotel. In the meantime for the rates I paid I was pleasantly surprised. My room was superb, the bed was out of this world and the location of the hotel couldn't have been better, great location and extremely quiet.My only gripes are that the bar is expensive, the staff could do with being trained on how to deal with customers the Jumeirah way, and the internet was not free! :(Would I stay there again? Yes, if the rates were as good as I got at the time :)

Jul 30 2006	NIce stay on the park	I was on a brief trip to New York where I knew I would have people coming to my hotel room and wanted to make a good impression. The Essex House, adjacent to Central Park delivered. I had one of the smaller suites. It had two bathrooms, a living room with a couch and two chairs, as well as a well appointed bedroom. The views were quite nice and the furnishings were adequate. Some of the items were a bit dated and showing use. However, in general the hotel was quite nice. The location is great. We took a good afternoon walk through the park to the Metropolitan Museum of Art (take a cab if you're not into long walks). When we returned from an evening on the town we had a final drink in the hotel bar. The crowd was nice and the service was great. The atmosphere in general was very nice. I'd recommend an Essex House stay to just about anyone.

Jul 17 2006	Hated it!!!	I booked my one night stay through broadway.com. I was told by the broadway.com rep that I would have a room with a view of Central Park. I had no such view. The room I had was in the back of the hotel, the only view was of other rooms. The water in the toilet ran continuously after flushing. I had to call the front desk twice because the tub was backed up. The first time someone came and did not resolve the problem even though he claimed that he had. The second time the problem was resolved. Later in the evening I was getting ready to go out and needed an iron. The iron in the room did not work properly so I called the front desk and asked for another one. I waited twenty minutes and still no iron. I called the front desk again and finally a working iron was brought up to my room. When I was ready for my night out I walked out to hail a cab. The doorman tried to take my cab and give it to a guest of the ballroom at this hotel. It was horrible and totally not worth the money. Checking in was also a terrible experience because the woman I spoke with was smug. I felt like an unwanted guest. I e-mailed my comments on the hotel website. I waited for 5 days and no answer. I e-mailed once again and received a response with an apology and was told that for my next stay I would receive a complimentary suite upgrade. Why would I possibly want to spend my hard earned money to stay there again. I do not recommend this hotel. I also e-mailed broadway twice and when I finally received a response I was disappointed. The rep apologized and then went on to state that they had positive reviews from other customers.

Jul 14 2006 	Loved it!!	We had a great stay at this hotel. The front desk was very helpful and the rooms were immaculately clean. We had just a standard queen room. The beds were fantastic and it was very quiet. The location is fantastic, right in front of central park, and within walking distance of great shops and times square.We will definately return to this hotel!

Jul 7 2006	Great hotel experience!	We finally found the perfect New York City hotel, and we plan to stay here every time we return to the city. We usually stay at Starwood hotels but the Essex House has been bought by the Dubai Arab-owned Jumeirah chain. They are in the middle of completely renovating this beautiful hotel though we couldn't hear or see any work being done. The gorgeous marble lobby welcomes you into a clam oasis from the excitement of the city. Directly across from Central Park between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, the location is perfect for Fifth Avenue shopping or Theatre District energy. We stayed in a fifth floor Park View room which was ideal for enjoying the green of the park and watching horse and carriages and park activities. The view from the upper floors is breathtaking if you prefer to be above it all. The beds are the comfortable Westin Heavenly beds though everything is going to be replaced. The furniture and rugs have a tired look so this is just in time. The service is outstanding, friendly and extremely prompt. My husband and I shared the large breakfast in our room. Everything was delicious and perfectly prepared. We asked for a fluffy down comforter and wool blanket which were delivered quickly. The rooms have doorbells by the way. We booked through Quikbook and got a very good rate.

Jul 3 2006	Better Than Expected	First of all, the location is perfect. Central Park is right across the street and major shop meccas within a 15 or twenty minute walk. The bed itself was comfortable, the bedding clean and not at all worn. Great workdesk with broadband. The bath amenities are top drawer - Penhagligon. The staff was friendly and accomodating. All in all, a very comfortable stay. Also found a great deal, which was a bonus ! I will be back.

Jun 6 2006	Will stay there next time	Stayed with my partner in Astor suite of Jumeirah Essex House on the week-end 26-29 of May. The price given on the web-site (USD 599) is absolutely great for the location and the huge suite, much better then with other 5 star neighbours. Really enjoyed excellent service and fantastic view on the Central park! Only small disapointment in service: requested 6 USD flat fare for the request to bring cutlery... strange for 5 star and suite quests. But will stay there next time for sure!!

May 24 2006	What a magnifcent place!!!!!	I was hesitant to stay at the Essex House after I read some of the reviews on Tripadvisor. All I can say is throw out the bad reviews! This place is magnificent!!!!The Tripsadvisor rating of #122 of 328 hotels is WAY too low. I was looking for any excuse to regret our decision to stay there and I NEVER found it. The people ar great, the room is superb with many amenities and the location on south Central Park is perfect. Believe it or not you can actually stay in New York and not hear sirens and horns all night! This is the place for your next New York trip.

May 12 2006 	Small rooms and old furniture	I stayed one night at Jumeirah Essex House on May 2, 2006. Had the room booked for 3 more nights but checked out the next day and moved to Tribeca Grand Hotel. Here's the reason why. My room was extremely small, 2 people barely fit. Furniture is very old with old TV tubes that didn't work well and toilet leaked. I called front desk twice and waited for someone to fix the toilet and no one ever came. If one is paying for quality, one should get quality specially if this hotel is rated with 4 stars which it doesn't deserve. And everyone around this hotel is old. So if you're over 50 this is the place to stay but if you're under 35 which I am, this is not the hotel for you! Only positive note, location which is across from Central Park and I had a park view room which was great but still not worth the tiny room with old furniture. Pay the same price and stay at a newely renovated hotel like Doubletree Midtown or W Midtown with flat screen TV and Tribeca Grand was awesome.

Apr 19 2006 	Unparalleled location excellent service!	Spent four nights at the Essex House and enjoyed the outstanding service as well as the superb location on Central Park South. The hotel welcomes guests with a warm & wet washcloth after they check in, and that sets the tone for the attentive service one receives from an eager to please to staff. My room lacked a view, but at the extraordinary price of $249 a night, how could I complain? Some of the nice touches: first class toiletries in the marble bathroom, a very comfortable mattress and more pillows than one would ever be able to use. The NY Times and Wall Street Journal were at my door every morning (even the Sunday Times on Sunday morning!).... For breakfast nearby, try the excellent PAIN QUOTIDIEN bakery on 7th Avenue & 58th Street. For lunch, a pastrami sandwich at the CARNEGIE DELI on 7th Avenue & 55th Street is a must (just don't get a hernia lifting it!).

Apr 6 2006	Great hotel fantastic location excellent service	Spent 5 nights at the Jumeirah Essex House in March 06, over St Patricks Day. The hotel is in a perfect location for shopping on 5th Ave, wandering in Central Park and of course, was fantastic for the St Patricks Day Parade.The reception and concierge staff are very helpful and the lobby itself is spectacular - beautiful flowers every day. The room was a good size and the beds very comfortable. Only negative was that the air conditioning was noisy and difficult to get the temperature just right.The bar is very pleasant (expensive, although that's hotel bars for you I guess!) and the bartenders are friendly.Its very easy to get around from the hotel, either by taxi or subway and its well positioned for all the usual sightseeing and shops.

Mar 29 2006	Very nice hotel.....	This hotel is excellently placed for tourists.We were on floor 10 in a deluxe park view room. The view really was excellent. The bedroom was a fair size, the bed was huge and very comfortable. The furniture and paintwork were a little tired although I think now the hotel is owned by Jumeirah it will have a makeover.I have stayed at Jumeirah hotels in Dubai and they really are 1st class.The bathroom was very nice with plenty of towels and toiletries.The lobby and elevator areas are amazing, very plush.All the staff were pleasant. The breakfast was lovely with very good service.There is a nice bar in the hotel with very tasty bar snacks. The service there was very fast.There are horse and carriages lined up opposite the hotel, we took one on a ride around the park, definately worth doing!We will certainly use this hotel again. It will be good to see exactly what Jumeirah do to it.

Mar 25 2006	Enjoyable Stay at Essex House	We had booked this hotel for a special trip when it was still part of the St Regis brand so were a bit apprehensive after reading some of the other recent reviews particularly those written after the take over by Jumeirah. We needn't have worried. Check-in was smooth, the room was a fairly good sized park view room (excellent outlook) on the 32nd floor which meant it was away from the street and quiet and we found the staff to be friendly and helpful without exception. We had two minor gripes which, whilst not detracting from our trip prevented us from awarding the hotel 5 out of 5. The first was the complimentary drinking water in the room which is not replenished on a daily basis. Jumeirah expect that guests should purchase water from the mini bar. Not really acceptable for a hotel of this standard. Also the robes only materialised on the last night of our 4 day stay. As a hotelier myself, I know that it is the little touches that matter and Jumeirah fell short on these. It is early days though and we would certainly return to this hotel after the planned refurbishment to see how things have progressed.

Mar 4 2006 	Reliable and comfortable	Stayed here several times over the years when it was a Westin, and recently after change in management.This is a traditional grand hotel, magnificent lobby, plush public areas, top-notch service. Standard rooms like I stayed in are a bit small and usually don't have views, but do (still) have the Heavenly bed, expensive decor, and nice baths. On my most recent visit, I noted the room could use a little freshening, even though housekeeping is fine.Location is a mixed bag. Directly on Central Park, which is great in nice weather, but a little removed from midtown.TripAdvisor doesn't allow half-star ratings but if it did, I would rate 3.5 stars rather than 3.

Feb 17 2006	Mixed bag	We stayed 4 nights at the Essex House. Had stayed there two years before. This trip, though, we got off to a bad start. Had requested in my email reservation to have a high floor. Requested a park view queen room. My husband walked up to the desk and was told that the room would be on the third floor...all others not yet available until 3 pm. He came and told me...I said we would wait. He went back to the desk and said we would wait (I had read that the low floors facing the park were noisy). All of a sudden a room on the 7th floor suddenly became available! Give me a break...we took it. Got to the room. Upon first use of the toilet, it wouldn't quit flushing...water was just pouring thru it like Niagara Falls. Finally my husband went in the bathroom, took off the lid and made some sort of adjustment and it stopped flowing. Room looked ok, just like 2 years before. But...my husband was sleeping closest to the heat duct (in the ceiling) and it made a vibration as it cycled on and off all night long. He didn't sleep well. Called downstairs the first morning and they said they would fix it. Got back to room late for the second night's sleep and it was not fixed. Upon calling downstairs, they said the engineer had been there and had done something to it. We tried letting the fan run continuously the second night and it was a little better but not much. Meanwhile in the bathroom, the lighting was terrible. Can light over the toilet was burned out. Can light over the sink was very dim...something like a 67 watt bulb and it was about 8 to 10 inches up inside the can. A makeup mirror with a little light on it was attached to the wall beside the sink but you couldn't get at it to see yourself...totally useless. Also this day we were left with no wash cloths at all. My husband complained about the vibrating heating system again and this time he was still in the room when the engineer came. The guy was nice and trying to help. Thought he helped it but soon it became obvious that it was reverting to its original ways. The next day I let the engineer in after calling and watched what he did. Noticed that the furnace filter seemed to rub against something. Also saw a previous repair job consisted of jamming a towel up inside the thing! Engineer left. I left. My husband came back to our non-smoking room a bit later and said the smell of cigarette smoke was overwhelming, as if somebody had just left the room while smoking. Offended, he called back downstairs. They offered to move us for about the 4th time (but I didn't want to suffer thru all the packing again). Now it's the third night...vibrations start up. We take my nail file and open the ceiling panel. Take out the furnace filter and close the lid back up. No more vibrations! So for the third and fourth nights we did get some sleep--both of us. I complained about all this downstairs at the desk. They called for the front end manager to meet me over at the desk. Nicki was very nice...very understanding and apologetic. Told about the big takeover and the soon to be infusion of big cash for remodelling. I told her about the light in the bathroom and the heat. Felt for this price we deserved more. She said to please give them another chance and come back in about a year for another try...poor thing, she was trying. I knew that since I had pre-paid for the room we couldn't get anything back so I didn't even ask. Mainly all you want back is your time, not money, anyway, but I knew she couldn't do anything about that. It just left us with a sour taste in our mouths, I guess. All staff we encountered were very helpful and courteous. They did replace the bulb over the toilet, too. As time passes the irritation fades. Great location for 56 year olds who need to do the sightseeing in little spurts thru the day. Good place for popping back in the room to drop off stuff, rest, etc.

Feb 2 2006	Awful	We checked in on 12/23/05 for 3 nights. The gentleman who checked us in had the personality of a stone, no greeting whatsoever! We paid additional for a park view room and requested a room on a higher floor. Upon entering our room after using the toilet, it would not stop running. After contacting front desk and waiting 30 minutes for engineering, I went down to the front desk. The only other room in the entire hotel with a park view was on the 3rd floor! Upset but needing to unpack due to theatre tickets, I checked out the room. The toilet was running in this room as I unlocked the door! Back to the front desk, now they only had a smoking room.2 hours after "checking in" we finally got to speak with Hector in engineering, he promised to take care of us after he was given a $$ tip. We ended up with a room on the 16th floor. The room was very small and the bathroom could have been alot cleaner. Not once during our stay did we come across a friendly employee, stone cold looks!In addition, we never received any sort of apology.

Jan 29 2006	OK experience	The good things about this hotel are the fabulous location right on Central Park South and the polite and helpful staff. Jan 25 2006	Just sold to Jumeriah - renovations planned	Thjis is a very nice hotel although not at all your typicaly Westin, which perhaps explains why it was just sold to the Jumeriah chain of luxury hotels. Jan 22 2006	It's all about service	We stayed in an interior room ($379) before xmas and departed on the first day of the transit strike. When we returned, a few hrs. later, our bags were not in the room and we had to hunt them down via/front desk/housekeeping. Jan 16 2006	You can't beat the location! One of Midtown's best	We've always stayed at the Essex House when in Manhattan primarily due to the excellent location and the fact it was a Starwood Property. Jan 13 2006 	This was the perfect place to stay.	The Essex House scored high on two scales: location and comfort. Since Central Park and the nearby museums were such an important feature of my vacation, being able to step out the doors of the hotel and cross the street into the magnificent park was a huge treat for me. The Essex House is very comfortably within walking distance of the Metropolitan Museum, the Museum of Natural History, and the great shops on Fifth Avenue. Maybe it's just a little too close to Fifth Avenue.My room was comfy but not stuffy (although, because I stayed on a lower floor with an 'Inner View', I was treated to all the middle of the night noises that make New York special: cars, trucks, sirens). The Westin chain's sumptuous 'Heavenly Bed' really is a treat for a bad back like mine and it helps restore the body after days of walking (the reason most Manhattanites seem to be very fit). My room was satisfyingly clean and well appointed. The 'Heavenly Bath' - consisting of a two-headed massage shower head, crescent curtain (for more elbow room), marble floor and sink surround, and luxury amenities - was compact but easy to move around in. My only complaint about the room would be that it seemed to be slightly dilapidated; in the bathroom, wallpaper was loose in several places and hanging from the wall in a strip - and, despite my mentioning this a member of the housekeeping staff, no effort was made to correct it. I later learned that the entire hotel is slated for renovation this year, so that may explain its having 'slipped' a little in the maintenance department. However, guests should not have to bear any burden because of this. We pay for immediate comfort, not future improvement. The wallpaper should have been fixed.I did not have the opportunity to dine in one of the hotel's fine restaurants (which I regret), but dining in my room was an enjoyable experience. The room service staff were accommodating and pleasant. The Journeys lounge was a cosy, lovely environment for hanging out with friends over a drink and a delightful snack.Without exception, the hotel staff were efficient, respectful and pleasant.I'm not sure what's in the future for the Essex, since it was acquired by the Dubai Jumeira group and will cease to be a Westin hotel this year. Since the Jumeira group has announced that they will continue to operate it as a hotel (albeit with fewer rooms), I believe that it will continue to be an even lovelier experience for visitors to the city. My only selfish concern is that, after the proposed renovation and management transition, it may be much pricier.Overall, a delightful experience, and one I'd love to repeat.

Jan 12 2006	Great Location Good Looking Hotel	Brilliantly located for Mid/Up Town. Dec 21 2005	Not bad	Had a pleasant enough stay here considering I booked the cheapest rate they had (still over $400 but for NYC in Decemeber that is what it costs for any decent hotel)I put a premium on space and the Essex House scores big there. Dec 21 2005	Will keep coming back!	The Essex House has become our home away from home in NYC. Nov 28 2005	Nice getway	Had a romantic, weekend-getaway in NYC. Room was very clean, comfortable, typically NYC small (but not cramped). Our room had a 6th-floor (treetop-level) view of Central Park. Nov 28 2005	Great time at the Essex House	I had a wonderful time at the Essex House over the Thanksgiving holiday with my family. Nov 20 2005	An interesting Westin	Why Westin puts its name on the Essex House remains a mystery to me. It was just so different from your typical Westin. In many ways, it reminded me of the Waldorf. The lobby was decorated in a conservative/traditional style, but it lacked the grandeur and scale of the Waldorf or even the run-down Plaza. The room I got was on the small side, and the "Heavenly" amenities were nothing special. Service was quite poor - snobbish staff without the class to back it up.What really bothered me was the fact that this hotel was neither grand nor intimate. The Carlyle and the Mark are small, but they leverage on their size to offer personalized service that creates a home-away-from-home for their guests. The Waldorf and the Plaza go the opposite by impressing you with their grand public spaces. They are all clear about their strengths and weaknesses, and they position themselves accordingly.In this case, the Essex House took the worst of both worlds - impersonal service and unimpressive public spaces. Is this a bad hotel? Absolutely not. But for the rate I paid, I expected much more.

Oct 27 2005 	Hated to leave!	We stayed at the Essex October 11 through the 21st. Oct 21 2005	Magic CAN happen!	I spent five nights at this hotel in mid October. I originally chose it because of its proximity to Central Park and I was not prepared for how wonderful the experience was. Because my plane from California landed at JFK at 6AM I couldn't get checked into my room until noon but the helpful girl at the reception desk told me I could leave my luggage there (safely), go to the park or wherever, come back at noon, and go through the check-in process. This worked perfectly. I had made my reservation by phone in April and had requested a high floor on the park side. I was, in no way, prepared for the view: three huge and sparkling clean windows overlooking the park. I could see all the way to the Bronx. It had been raining for a week and the park sparkled. The city lights sparkled at night. The sight was amazing and worth every penny that I paid for that room.Not everything, however, was as perfect as that view, but the things I had problems with were very minor and very fixable. Housekeeping had left no washcloths one morning. One request brought some and they appeared ever after. The toilet seat was one of those flimsily attached by flexible plastic and it wiggled all over. The toilet had a habit of running but after handle jiggling, it stopped. The water pressure, even as high up as I was, was fantastic...in the sink and in the shower. The shower was excellent, once I figured out the controls. It would have been helpful to have had a primer on the operation because it was rather unique. The bed, as has been previously mentioned, was soft and cushy and clean. The carpet had a few stains but so what. Designer water available for $5.00 but nobody said you have to buy it. Tap water was fine! Lighting...lots of it and plenty of watts. Roominess in the room? A desk, a loveseat, an easy chair, a monster size bed, a chest of drawers with top space for luggage, two huge closets, a big TV, an end table by the bed, a table by the chair, three phones (I'm sure I've forgotten something), and still lots of space. Of all the positive things about the Essex the best of all was the human element. To a man, and woman, ALL staff was professional, professionally dressed, friendly, helpful, and cheerful. The gentlemen out on the sidewalk could get a cab in a jiffy and didn't mind arguing with drivers and calling security on drivers they thought might be trying to stiff the hotel guests. I witnessed one such exchange. Oh, the power of those Essex doormen! They were terrific. Would I go back? In a New York minute. Thank you, Essex House. I miss you already. My own bed and shower and view seem very, very lame. I almost forgot...because the hotel's check out time is noon, and because my plane didn't leave Kennedy until 7PM, once again the hotel allowed me to keep it as my base of operations (they stored my luggage and allowed me to use the "facilities" when I wasn't in the park and finally, their super doormen hailed one last cab for me and got my luggage safely stored in the trunk of the cab). Boy, did I hate to leave. I had the feeling there that I was being well taken care of and completely safe. I think a tourist or traveler would be wise to stay at the Essex House. I am sitting here in sunny Southern California thinking about what the first snowfall would look like from those windows. California dreaming is turning into New York City dreaming.

Aug 28 2005	A week at the Essex House	Nine of us travelled from Aberdeen, Scotland to stay at the Essex House for one week on 28th July 2005. Aug 25 2005	No Customer Service Here	After living in Manhattan for a year, I took my father back with me for an annual visit to New York. Jul 20 2005	Fantastic!	First, the location is amazing. It was done without hassle! Fantastic!things to do - the Hard Rock Cafe NY was right up the street, about 2 blocks. Fantastic! It was a great hotel, great service and great staff. I would Def. stay there again!OH! and if your lucky, maybe you'll meet someone famous. We did! Our check in clerk upgraded my husband and I to a park-view room as soon as my husband cheekily mentioned that it was our wedding anniversary. The bell man came across the road to greet us, carry our bags and to argue with our limo driver (who had dropped us off across 4 lanes of traffic away from the hotel!). Our room was gorgeous - the view was only an added bonus. The room was plenty big enough, the bed - can't describe how comfortable - shower was great, it was clean and really comfortable.The two sets of parents didn't get park-views, but GIANT rooms, with equally GIANT king beds (the queen we had seemed to be the same as a king here, the king bed was the same as two double beds pushed together!) and also incredibly comfortable (you definitely need a good nights sleep after all the walking we did!).We ate breakfast in the hotel on the first morning for a treat, and although rather pricey, was delicious and worth every penny (there's a great place around the corner - the Parisienne - which does a more reasonable and 'real NY' breakfast).We ordered hot drinks from room service that were so fast and so hot, delivered with flowers and a flourish - the waiter was incredibly polite, insisting on tidying up our (very messy!) console table in order that he could safely place the hot drinks down.Reception were more than happy to change my mum's trillions of travellers cheques (don't know if you've been before, but New York is NOT the place to take travellers cheques - stores seem to hate them) at all hours of the day and night and the staff were always cheerful and always told us what the weather was planning to do.We got this hotel for a bargain through Priceline and as far as we were concerned, the hotel was robbed! After reading the reviews on here before we went, I was really worried (this trip had all been arranged by me!), but I really think that Americans must be a little more picky than the British - this hotel is just great to stay in, right on the park, right near the subway and near great shops on 5th Avenue etc... We were not once disrupted by cleaners (or lack of cleaning) and no one was rude to us. I did witness one lady yelling at many different hotel staff, and can only conclude that you get what you give - we were very polite and the staff treated us with equal respect. Perhaps if you go around giving out bad vibes, bad things happen to you!Definitely would recommend this hotel and wouldn't hesitate to stay there again.

Apr 20 2005	Superb In Every Way	I took my 8-year-old son on a father-son bonding trip to New York last week. I struggled with where to stay; I like to avoid midtown, but felt like for his first trip we should stay in a more touristy area. I finally settled on the Essex House and am glad I did!I had used Starwood points to get a really great rate, but that meant we were destined for a brick wall view. I asked if there was any way we could swing a park view, and the desk clerk cheerfully upgraded us to a spacious (at least by NYC standards) room facing Central Park. The location was great; we walked nearly everywhere, and my son loved going to the park every day to play and climb rocks. The staff was incredibly gracious, the food was excellent and they really went all out for room service, with fresh flowers on linens on the table that was left in the room (even when all I had ordered was a bowl of soup!) Everyone treated my son like royalty, which I really appreciated. As usual, the "Heavenly" bed and shower were great. The concierge was helpful and friendly. And I was able to secure a 3:00 p.m. checkout time, which with our plans for our final day really helped us.Top to bottom, just a stellar experience.

Apr 20 2005	Worst Hotel ever - do not waste your money there.......	My partner and I decided to stay at this "top" hotel from April 7th through to the 11th, as it was my birthday on the 8th April. The first evening we got there, I noticed that our toilet was starting to fill up and I thought it would overflow and spill out all over the bathroom floor. I reported this at reception at 5pm and we assumed it would be fixed, while we were out for the evening. We returned at 11pm and no one had been all that time! I went down to reception and complained and they apologised but confirmed that no one had been in. They said it must have been a "break down in communications". We then had to move rooms at 11.45pm that evening (so repack our bags and cases) and were given two breakfast vouchers by way of compensation.The rest of the holiday seemed fine, but as soon as I got back to London I was told that my brother had organised 35 pounds worth of flowers, to be sent to me at the hotel for the morning of my birthday (April 8th). They NEVER ARRIVED. The receptionist confirmed that I was a guest there, when the driver dropped the flowers off and assured him they would be delivered. WHERE DID THEY GO? I have also found out that two friends called me from London on my birthday - I didnt get any messages, and remember checking my voicemail twice that day (as you would on your birthday!) I have contacted the hotel - who are looking into it all. That was last week and STILL no reply or call from them - 5 working days later. DO NOT STAY at this hotel -- its the worsty 5 star hotel I have stayed in and they ruined my birthday weekend.

Mar 20 2005	Perfection at the Essex House	I planned a first trip to the big city for my niece's 16th birthday. Our trip coincided with "The Gates" installation at Central Park. For this reason I booked a park-view room at the Essex House in September of 2004 at a price of $289 per night. Luckily I did book that early because as the buzz of the Christo work spread park-view rooms quickly became scarce. I was worried that perhaps we would be given an inferior room because I was not a frequent customer and had no Starwood points. I did sign up for the Starwood program before our trip. Our flight departed early in the morning and we got to the Essex House at 10am, thinking we would have to deposit our luggage and come back at check-in time. To my surprise we were escorted immediately to our room. Check-in was quick, efficient and extremely courteous and the view from our 10th floor room was perfect. We had a picture-perfect view of the Gates and all of Central Park. The bed was huge and inviting, triple sheeted, a down duvet and lots of pillows. The bathroom, although not extremely large was marble and had a great two-headed shower, a phone by the toilet and a lighted make-up mirror mounted by the sink. The only bad thing I could say was that there was no counter space in the bathroom. We requested something to be brought up to the room and when the waiter arrived he rang our DOORBELL. My niece was especially impressed with that. We had a delicious three course prix fixe lunch for $25 a person at the downstairs Cafe Botanica. It has windows facing Central Park South. Service here was impeccable as well.Our stay could not have been more perfect at the Westin Essex House. Highly recommended!If you wish to see photos of our trip: (---)

Mar 12 2005	Not a great experience	My family travels into New York City an average of 2 weekends per month. We normally stay at the Hilton or Westin Times Square, as these are the most reliable hotels in terms of customer service and accommodations. We received an email offer for $199 at the Westin Times Square and decided to take advantage of this great rate. There were no rooms available at the Westin, but the offer was extended to the Essex House Westin on Central Park South. Being a native New Yorker, I grew up thinking of the Essex House as a very elegant hotel where celebrities stay. The lobby is reminiscent of 1930s grand style  classy and elegant. There was no wait at check in. When I booked the room, I explained that I needed one that was big enough for 3 people. I was told that the Deluxe Queen Park View room would be large enough to accommodate a roll away bed. Upon check in, I was told that was true- if we wanted to crawl over each other to get to the bathroom. The front desk clerk offered a king room with a partial park view (one small window that looks over the park  the other window looking directly into other hotel windows. I explained that we were celebrating my sons birthday and we really wanted what we booked  a nice park view. I knew they had suites available (I had just checked with reservations out of curiosity) and I asked to be upgraded (I am, after all a Starwood Preferred Guest). The clerk said he could not upgrade us as all the suites were spoken for. The room is on the small size with a little area that held the desk and closets. The bathroom was very small. You had to shut the door completely to get to the toilet.As other reviews stated, the windows are very drafty and you need to keep the drapes closed or you will freeze. The temperature control in the room was quirky. It was too hot or too cold, never perfect. The carpets were stained, giving the room a dingy appearance. They offer satellite TV, which is nice because you get a few more kids channels than most hotels offering cable.The heavenly bed that the Westin is famous for is just that. The bed, pillows and comforters were magnificent. We all slept like babies.Our second day started with a very pricy ($61 for 2 adults and a child) but elegant buffet breakfast in the lobby restaurant. The eggs were a bit runny but other than that it was lovely.Housekeeping was another issue. They only made the bed. They did not refresh our towels, make up the rollaway or do any other maintenance in the room. We returned to the room at about 2:30 to see linens in the corner of the room, the rollaway stripped but not done up and no clean towels. A few minutes later, a housekeeper barged into the room without knocking. She backed out of the room embarrassed and never returned. I went to the front desk to complain and was assured that the problem would be fixed immediately. I also requested a refrigerator, which never arrived. We left and returned nearly an hour later and nothing had been done. It was time to get management involved.The manager was pleasant enough and said it was not the Essex Houses policy to have rooms half serviced, nor was it their policy for housekeeping to barge in without knocking. When I addressed the issue of the refrigerator, she told me to take everything out of the minibar and use that. I told her I was uncomfortable with that but she insisted that it was ok to do. I think its poor form to ask a guest to assume the responsibility of emptying the miniibar and making sure everything gets back in. She said she would send up a fridge if I insisted. Finally, housekeeping arrived (again entering the room without knocking) to bring towels. The manager offered to upgrade us next time we come into the city. If I were going to pay top dollar, Id rather book a room at the Hiltons Executive floor or the Westin Times Square. If you need to be on Central Park South, Im sure there are better choices.

Mar 9 2005 	Enjoyed the Essex House	Spent four nights at the Essex House in February 2005. For the price I thought it was one of better values I have found in NYC. Room was fairly big by New York standards, clean and comfortable. I would certainly return.

Mar 4 2005	Great location very nice room but??	My husband and I stayed here Feb 24-26, and picked the location to be close to "The Gates" in Central Park. As Starwood "gold" status, we wereupgraded to a room on the 25th floor (2505) where there is "butler" service.While the "butler", who came to the room shortly after we arrived was veryprofessional, she never appeared when we paged her a few hours later.We had a room with 2 queen beds, and a view facing NW, with a partial view over Central Park. The "heavenly" beds are indeed quite good, the linens very high-end, and the furniture and ambiance overall quite nice.The bathroom was huge, and gratis toiletries wonderful, as well as the large box of truffles provided upon arrival.Only problem was, as cited by other guests on tripadvisor, the drafts coming in from the windows. The very heavy (and lovely) draperies kept the drafts out when closed, but when opened it was somewhat cold in the room. At about $350 night, (no breakfast), we felt it was a fair price for the overallquality at a hotel in NYC. We had stayed at the Warwick the month before for $250/night, and the difference between the two hotels is much more than the price differential we experienced.This is definitely a "get what you pay for" place.. I suspect that you're not going to be happy getting with a $200 room here through hotels or expedia.

Feb 8 2005	Try something else next time	Just came back from NYC(02/06/05). Stayed 2 nights at essex house for about 245 per night for 10th floor deluxe room with park view. Outside of building looks very run down. Lobby is very plain. Check in was great, very friendly and fast. Got 2 'pink' coupons for breakfast at botanicas restaurant. 'pink coupons' lets you eat buffet plus menu items at no charge. Breakfast is fantastic. Room was spacious and nice view of the park but higher floor would have been nice. Marble bathroom was on the small side with no where to put your things but was very clean. Bed is nice but at the end of the day it's just a bed. Concierge at night was very nice and recommended ' la vineria ' italian restaurant just a couple of blocks away. It was great. Tried the same thing with the concierge during the day and she ------. Total attitude. Don't think will stay there again since you don't get what you paid for. There are Holiday Inns that are just as nice. Would like to try the W or the Westin Hotel in time square next time. Bye,

Jan 23 2005	Great experience at a corporate hotel	Checked in for two nights on January 14th and were given the room we had booked -- queen bed with Central Park view -- on the 5th floor. Sure, the room was small for what one would expect, but in NYC as it is in Europe, space is a premium. We heard some street noise, but were not bothered by the occasional horn honk or the clopping of horse hooves as the carriages strolled by. Isn't that part of the charm of staying off Central Park? The "Heavenly" bed was quite comfortable and the white linens crisp and luxurious. The "Heavenly" everything else -- from the towels to the toiletries were nothing special. Complaints: Front desk staff not so helpful at check-in. There were three people behind the desk and they all needed to help the one couple who had credit card problems -- rather then help the couple that were ready to go (and the only other people in line). The concierge ladies were not knowledgeable and seemed to only mention the same bistro to guest after guest seeking restaurant recommendations. Overall, we would stay at the Essex House again if we desired a room overlooking Central Park. We are torn between staying here or at the Algonquin (where we stayed in September 2004). The dilemma: Do we prefer a fancy room (Essex House) or superior service (Algonquin)?

Jan 16 2005	Essex House what about Essex Closet?	When visiting NY I usually stay in hotels on Central Park: Plaza (temp closing), Mayflower (Trump?) Park Lane, St. Moritz (now the Ritz), and Essex House. The staff was wonderful. From check-in to check-out everyone working at the Essex House were highly professional. The building's architecture, lobby, public rooms, and park location, spectacular. My room was another story. The room was on par with the Plaza. Old, soiled, small, and expensive. I had a park view room on the 11th floor. The "view" window was small and single paned. It was snowing ouside and the room was absolutely freezing. Cold air was seeping in from the unsealed pane, which was so thin I was able to hear the horses hoofs on the pavement (charming); as well as yells, horns, sirens, and conversations (not charming). The smallish plush queeen bed took up ALL the space in the room but was very comfortable. The carpets were stained yet the soft down comforter was a pristine white. The grey and white marble bathroom, very clean. And once again, the location can't be beat. Would I stay here again? No. But I was glad I experienced one stay at the historic Essex House .

Jan 3 2005	First Big City Adventure	My husband's 50th birthday was celebrated at the Essex House, Central Park So. from 12/27/04 thru 12/30/04. We consider the Grand Hyatts our luxury hotels, so this was a new experience. We requested a room upgrade as the first shown was overlooking buildings towards the rear of the hotel. This was granted after some gentle assertiveness and our room on the 10th floor had a fab view of the park. The bed was indeed heavenly, the bath large and with a tub to accomadate the birthday boys 6 ft. 5 in. heigth and 300 lbs. frame ! The furnishings were in good condition and 2 closets for plenty of hanging space. I had requested some surprise goodies be prepared for his arrival....Perrier, navel oranges, chocolates, cheese, and fruit and crackers and this was very nicely presented with 2 roses. We found the staff to be very gracious and service was good. Our usual room service delights were curtailed as we found the cost excessive. The one morning we opted to have breakfast in the Botanica dining room we spent 28.00 plus tip and tax to total about 38.00 for 2 bowls of McCann oatmeal and 2 coffees. This is definitely a heist of the first order!! In my opinion, that is....Other mornings we had our breakfast at wonderful restaurants close by. We did not even consider the dining experience at the Ducasse room...At 150.00 prix fix that was way too out of our budget! In any event, the location, service, cleanliness and overall atmosphere at the Essex was very solid and we felt satisfied with our stay and first "Big City Adventure". I would only hope for an in room coffee maker so we could have that first am jolt close at hand and not have to order up a 10.00 cup via room service (That would be with the 18% gratuity and room service charges etc, etc. We will return someday to NYC and hope to see more of the museums and enjoy more of the city..We would most definitely consider the Essex House.

Jan 2 2005	Very nice with a couple of "buts"	Super convenient location for Central Park, major shopping, the subway, eating out and Broadway. Nice attentive staff and beautifully styled inside. The couple of "buts" are that our room was smaller than we had imagined and as shown in most photos we had found, just enough room to move around the bed, and that the bath itself was very small. We suspect this is because we had a cheaper room as we booked through Expedia and got a great price. The bed was lovely and was, as advertised, a "Heavenly Bed" and the shower was good. But the rest was OK, not fantastic but certainly not poor. We had Christmas Lunch in the hotel's Cafe Botanica and. although pricey, it was excellent. So overall I would recommend the Essex House on location alone but pay the extra for a bigger room if you really want something special rather than average.

Dec 31 2004	Great location unacceptably shabby room.	We stayed here on 12/28 for one night. I booked a 1 bedroom exterior view suite using my Starwood Preferred Points. We were assigned room 1723, which had a sign on it indicating it was a Starwood Preferred Guest Room.The Suite was huge and overlooked rooftops and one tower of the Time Warner Building. It had a small foyer, powder room and small living room with pull-out sofa and desk. The bedroom had a king sized bed, 2 night tables, a bench with a drawer and an armoir with a tv. Past the bedroom was a dressing room with no furniture but a large closet and safe. I found this area to be cold no matter what temperature the rest of the room was set on. The bathroom was suprisingly small considering the size of the rest of the suite. There was little (ie, no) counter space in the bathroom, and there was a small tub/shower with 3 shower heads (the heavenly shower), a bidet and toilet. The wallpaper, carpet and bed were new and clean. These were the exception. The rest of the room was unacceptably shabby - to the extent that it looked like a rock (ie metal) band had stayed there and trashed the room. The door to the room was banged with gashes and peeling paint that was visible from the hall. The armoir in the living room had chunks taken out of if and the door that covered the minibar had been literally ripped off of the unit, leaving a big gash in the unit and exposing the minibar. All other furniture was dented with peeling paint. In the bathrooms the countertops were pulling away from the sink bases. In the main bath, the tub was old and showed discoloration and there was some mold visible under the caulking around the tub.Service in the hotel was mostly good, and everyone we encountered was pleasant and helpful. Notable errors were that no one had cleaned up the mini bar area from the prior guests, who had eaten most of what was in there and left the trash behind. I had to ask 3 people before this was cleaned and replenished (we did not use it, but I did not want to be charged for the prior guests' use). We also confirmed turndown service twice and asked that the pull out sofa be opened and set up so my kids could sleep on it. When we arrived late in the evening, we had been given turn down service, but no one opened the sofa or even left linens for it. We then had to call and wait for this to be taken care of (we could not take care of it ourselves as there were no extra linens or pillows in the room).Food throughout the hotel was expensive but good. The toiletries in the bathroom were from Moulton Brown and were terrific. I would not hesitate to stay here again for free, but if I had paid the $650 that I was quoted for the room rate, I would have been upset at the shabbiness of the room.By the way, the Heavenly Bed is just that!

Dec 30 2004	Wonderful Hotel!	This Hotel was worth every penny...even though I didn't have to empty my pocket. If you sign up for a Starwood Perferred Guest membership you get awesome discounts on all their hotels and extra benefits. I especially love their hotel chain because of their extra comfy beds. We were even upgraded for free. Everything was clean and the plumming worked great. We loved the location, nice and quiet and close to everything.

Dec 23 2004	Great Location Great Service!	My boyfriend and I have just returned from a beautiful Christmas visit to the city! We had booked the Essex House through an Internet offer I had received directly from Starwood hotels. It really pays to sign up for these programs, even if you dont stay that often! We booked our DEC 21st stay for a mere $179! Service was great from the moment we pulled up- the bellman took care of our luggage and our car was valet parked ($49 indoor garage parking for 24 hr period, no in/out privileges.) We were promptly checked in and given an upgrade to a king size corner room, simply because I had notated special romantic occasion on the comments section of the online booking form. The clerk was apologetic that he couldnt give us a king with a view of the park as they were all taken, but could give us a queen with a park view in a smaller room. Being that it was already dark outside, we graciously accepted the larger king. How Generous! And to think for $179 in Manhattan!The room was impeccably clean and comfortable. Dcor was clean and sophisticated with masculine colors and minimal furnishings. There were his and her closets, complete with automatic lighting elements a nice touch. The bathroom was a dark black marble with vintage styled fixtures. We called downstairs to the concierge who called ahead to the restaurant- Daniel a must try to let them know we were running late for our reservation. He offered to go ahead and ask the bellman to secure us a cab as well, which was waiting for us when we got downstairs. The next morning was peaceful with breakfast in bed very delicious, but definitely over priced at $23 for an egg/meat/pastry/OJ/Coffee combination. PLUS tax, 16% gratuity and a $3pp delivery charge, tallying up to an $80 breakfast for two, but who wanted to get out of bed to go to the diner around the block?We non-chalontly checked out at 12:30pm, without a word being said and no late fees before leaving our luggage in storage. We went ahead and enjoyed the city all day- WALKING EVERYWHERE WE WENT! The location of the Essex house is unbeatable! Upon return, our luggage was promptly retrieved from storage and loaded into our car waiting out front, while we enjoyed cocktails by the fireplace at the hotel bar, Journeys. Yes, $14 for each Martini, but it was a very cozy way to end our delightful stay! All in all, for Manhattan, this was an unbeatable value we had first class comfort and service for less than the price of the Holiday Inn! I dont think I would pay full price for this hotel though Just keep checking those specials!

Dec 12 2004	Great Place to Stay	After doing tons of research I decided to stay at the St. Regis in the Essex House. Although the price was extremely high (what do you expect when its just a few weeks before Christmas) we were very pleased with our room. We had a "Junior Suite" and it was terrific. Probably the only surprise was we did not have the usual Westin upgrades such as a heavenly bed, double shower, etc. Fortunately, we called Daisy, our housekeeper, and she had some heavenly bedding brought right up. She said the St. Regis rooms were due to be upgraded early in 2005. The lobby is very peaceful and elegant with all the people there being very knowledgeable about the hotel and the whole area. I would have no problem staying there again.

Dec 1 2004	Great Location But Otherwise Disappointing	The location is fantastic--close to Broadway theatres, excellent restaurants, shopping, and museums. I would've appreciated the Central Park South location much more if I'd have a park view, but instead I had a view of brick walls & ventilation ducts. I tried to use my Starwood points to upgrade my room, but Starwood makes it extremely difficult to do this--you have to wait till 5 days before arrival to even try to get an upgrade, and of course by then all the good rooms are gone. My room was sufficiently spacious, and the bed was very comfortable. The hotel decor is very dark & conservative--way too Ralph Lauren for my taste. The housekeeping staff members were very noisy, intrusive, and overly aggressive. I had to call to complain because they were slamming doors and making way too much noise in the morning. They also kept calling and knocking on my door, even though I had the "Do Not Disturb" sign on my door--it was incredibly irritating, & far below the standard I would expect from such an expensive hotel. I was really looking forward to staying at the Essex House, but overall, other than the great location, I'd have to say that it was a disappointment.

Nov 11 2004	Superb efficient and friendly	Just had a 5 night stay at the Essex House and enjoyed every minute of it. Slight problem when we were assigned a non-park view room, but a quick phone call to reception and ten minutes later we were in the 3rd floor park view room we had wanted with a great view though the trees into Central park (and a birds eye view of the Marathon!). The staff were always friendly, helpful and efficient, and we had no problems with check-out (despite asking for a late check-out), towncar airport transfer booking and luggage storage as we had a late flight back from Newark airport.The food is excellent, albeit expensive. Room service was fast with the hot, freshly made delicious meals (can heartily recommend the BLT, Cheesecake, and Ice Cream Sundae!). Breakfast at the Cafe Botanica was very nice and allowed us to watch the poor New Yorkers going off to work down Central Park South as we enjoyed a buffet breakfast, though it got a little loud with Businness people during weekdays. Cheaper food options include a Rays Pizza (very cheap but good pizza slices) just opposite the rear entrance of the hotel and the La Parisienne Deli just round the corner on 7th Avenue where we had delicious American style Breakfasts and quick evening meals in a typical American/New York style Deli/Diner just up the street from Carnegie Hall. Heartily recommended.

Nov 9 2004	Very Nice for the price I got...	Got a great corporate rate here while in town for business. I had stayed at the Hilton and Sheraton over the previous 4 weeks or so - then found this rate. I jumped on it because, well, it's the Essex House. Was not disappointed. A very nice room, that wonderful bed that you find at all Westin properties, a nice staff though not overwhelmingly friendly (except for the gentlemen that was by the elevators every day). Yes, it is old like most NY hotels. ANd most of their rooms do not have a view of the park unless you really want to pay for it. But, if you can get a good rate, why not stay here? It is a little bit of a treat for us road warriors to stay in a place that is not like all the other chains.I did not eat at the hotel...but hear it's very good - and expensive. But that's NY.I'd stay here again if I need to be in this part of town and can get my corp rate.

Nov 2 2004 	Too many better options in NY	Very surprised to read other reviews listed here. Travel to NY very frequently and was very disappointed in this Hotel. Yeah, it's on the Park but most rooms don't face it and those that do face the Park are closet size. Actually changed rooms 4 times (which I never do). Hotel is far too expensive not to have a decent room. Front desk clerk was downright rude and nasty. Hotel lobby is busier than Grand Central Station. Many New Yorkers use lobby to cross from 59th to 58th Street.. Creates chaotic, unwelcoming atmosphere. Hotel also nickels and dimes you for everything. $10 pp to use fitness center, $10 to have wine glasses brought to room, huge phone and internet fee, etc.Only highlight was restaurant and lounge atmosphere. That's it.

Oct 28 2004	Magnificent and cozy.	Lovely, centric, cozy luxurious hotel. It's quite expensive but worth it. Located right in front of Central Park. The restaurant is superb. The rooms are the top of the top. And the sheets... well... delicious. One of the best hotels I've ever stayed at.

Oct 25 2004	Awesome location reasonable price very comfortable bed	The Essex House is in an awesome location right on Central Park. Our room was the basic room with a park view. The room wasn't huge but more than sufficient. The room had a great view of the park being directly across the street. The heavenly bed was the best bed I've ever slept on. I thought my bed at home was good but the heavenly bed was better. The shower had a nice double shower head system that worked great. The staff was always friendly and helpful. There were a couple of minor down sides of the room. The paint above the shower was peeling as was some wall paper in the bathroom. Also, the first night, there was a hole in one of the sheets. The Essex House overall was great and I would definitely stay there again.

Oct 5 2004	Our Favorite Hotel in NYC!	My husband and I stayed at the St. Regis Club at the Essex house for 4 nights last week and what a wonderful time we had. We were upgraded to a wonderfully appointed suite because of our Starwood Gold Preferred membership. Our bed was so comfortable and I wanted to take it home, as well as the shower. However, the staff is absolutely superd. Our housekeeper Daisy was a gem, she made sure our suite was perfect. She is a real asset to the hotel. Nina, the concierge was absolutely unrelenting in her pursuit to get us reservations at Elaines and Babbo, and she succeeded! She also made some wonderful recommendations to some other restaurants. I wish all concierge's were as diligent and kind as she was. To sum it up, we had a great trip, and this will be the only hotel we stay at for all future New York City trips.

Sep 17 2004	Best Visit Ever	We stayed at the St. Regis Club part of the Essex House. I wanted a minimum 350 sq ft room, which is pricy in NYC. $449/nite; 9/10/04- 9/12/04. We were upgraded to the Astor Suite; Park View, 600+sq ft. Unbelievable! I felt like Humphrey Bogart was going to walk in carrying the Maltese Falcon. Perfect condition, beautifully decorated in muted colors; an actual apartment with dining room table at one end of the Living Room. Quiet yet across from Central Park where there are many free activities. It was a pleasant change from Times Sq. where we usually stay.

Sep 14 2004	Loved the Essex House.	Stayed at the Westin Essex House Labor Day weekend (9/3-9/6) with my 5 year old daughter. Truly wonderful experience. The park view was fantastic. I would definetely recommend getting one. We were on the 11th floor and obtained good rates from Starwood website on their "Buy 2 Nights Get One Night Free" promotion. Well worth every penny. Nice size room, well decorated and clean. Staff, conceirge were all very nice and helpful. My daugher loves Central park, as do I, so the location was perfect us. For everything else we made great use of the subway station located at 57th and 7th. Saw Beauty and the Beast one night, did Circle Line another night, carriage ride around the park. You are also down the street from Columbus Circle/Time Warner building. Lots of stores to check out, especially the Whole Foods Market. We mainly ate out, so I can't comment on room service or hotel restaurants. The bed is truly heavenly, as is the shower. I plan on returning and staying at the Essex around winter holiday.
Sep 9 2004	Great	So great! I liked the location, it made everything easy to walk. It was quiet. Use the South entrance to avoid the smell of horse droppings.

Aug 26 2004	Enjoyed The Essex House	My husband and I and our 2 teenage boys stayed at the Essex House July 31-Aug 3 2004. As SPG members we were upgraded to the St Regis level (higher floors of the hotel). The room was magnificent - a suite with a great view of Central Park. The downside was that it only had 1 bed (the couch didn't pull out). I called for rollaways, which then crowded the room. The front desk promised to take care of it the next day if we would please leave our bags packed. Well, like an episode of "While You Were Out" they moved us to an even larger suite in the Westin level (still with a park view) while we were out sight seeing. Both of the rooms we were in were clean and large. The staff was very professional and helpful, especially the doormen/bellhops. I didn't feel I got good service from the concierge, however. I asked her if there were any family-friendly restaurants in the area. She responded yes (very long pause). I had to then ask what they might be, then where they were! I didn't think I needed to play 20 questions. The location can't be beat. Right across the street from Central Park, close enough to Times Square and the theaters to walk - but not nearly as crowded or noisy. It was easy to pick up the double decker bus tour across the street, as well.

Sep 13 2009 	Absolutely gorgeous. Great for independent types.	If you want a concierge telling you where to go, and hot and cold running lattes and a spa with an in-house masseuse, this isn't the place for you. But if you like the privacy and peace of being in a real house, sleeping in a huge room (suite-sized, really), right smack bang in Noho just a stroll from Soho and Nolita and the LES and the West Village and well, everywhere, then this is the place for you. It's decoated, as mentioned, as though an eccentric, arty great-aunt did it in the late 40s and it hasn't been changed since. The bed is comfy (if a little noisy...), the tv is awesome (and has DVD player, HBO on demand, etc), the shower is INCREDIBLE and the bath is about four feet deep. One of the reviews alleged that it's not clean and everything is falling apart - completely untrue. It's spotless, and the threadbare rug is part of the charm, darling. Perhaps she'd be happier at a Marriott.The one thing that does need changing: the drapes. No matter how you arrange them, there's a two-inch crack on either side of the windows and light comes straight in. Not ideal for jetlag. There's no room service, as mentioned, but the B Bar and Grill next door does great coffee and brunch and incredible burritos, there's a sushi bar downstairs, Five Points around the corner does one of the best burgers I've ever tasted and well, it's New York. You're never going to starve, are you? Oh, and the staff, whilst not visible, are definitely available: I somehow broke the TV (damn remote controls) and sheepishly rang them to ask what to do. The guy came right up and fixed it within about one minute. That wouldn't be so quick in most hotels. I'd definitely stay here again... and I'd ask for a room with a courtyard. Those sound awesome.We go to NY a lot and tend to try new hotels each time... but I'm definitely coming back to Lafayette House. I wonder if I can get them to change the curtains first...

Oct 10 2008	Very charming but not for everyone	The hotel is in an excellent location between the NYU/village and the East Village. I was in NYC to enjoy the nightlife and shopping, not to sight-see. This is an old old building, 1848, "Gangs of New York" era if memory serves. This means that things are old and it is decorated in a similar style. If you are not used to real antiques and aren't fond of victorian style, this hotel won't be for you. If you like to be pampered by hotel staff 24/7 you won't like it. If you like to be left alone, you will. I do like it and It reminded me of similar old hotels in New Orleans. It is very charming but it is not full service, faux vintage "modern luxury" hotel. This also means it has no elevator and narrow steep victorian stairs. If you are person with mobility problems or disabilities, this hotel may be a no go for you unless you are on the ground floor. I stayed all the way on the top floor in a gigantic room. (pictured in the tripadvisor page) with a pleasant sitting area and fireplace. I had no noise problems, although I believe that your experience of this hotel *could* differ greatly depending upon which room you are in. Very important to me is the fact that the thick double paned windows of my room shut out the vast majority of the New York noise.. and best of all, they opened so I could enjoy fresh air if I wished. The cost was a fair value for New York ( New York hotel rates are way higher than the rest of the country) given the size of the room, but not if you were expecting modern fixtures. If you appreciate the style, this room would be excellent for a romantic get away (or for someone like me who appreciates a bit of history). It has a large deep bath tub. Negative is a shower that requires some arcane knowledge and skill to operate. Positive: I had several special requests that were met right away. In contrast to what some others have written, I found the hotel staff to be very cheerful and responsive. One possible warning: They are doing construction across the street. While I was staying there no work was being done, just a big hole in the ground, but I would check first. For me the mood, privacy, service and excellent location outweighed any negatives. I would definitely choose it again.

May 28 2008 	Amazing room	Last December as I was contemplating where to stay in Manhattan for my daughter's graduation from NYU , I received a card in the mail from Lafayette House which is owned by the same group as The Bowery. We were not disappointed.The doors are kept locked so you have to buzz the office to get in. We were led to our rooms which encompassed the entire first floor (below the entry level). These were by far the largest rooms we have had in NYC in the 15 or so trips we have made in the past 4 years. Each room had a sitting area with fireplace and my room even had a small kitchenette. The rooms are individually furnished with beautiful antiques. The bed was extremely comfortable and outfitted with first class linens. The highlight was the lovely courtyard that was shared by my room and the one my 2 high schoolers shared. It was the perfect place to unwind with a book after a day of walking the city.The only things I would change would be the bathroom in my room really should have been totally redone not just updated. The one in the kids room was and it was fabulous. Also the a/c unit was in an awkward location and did not include a remote so someone from the office had to come turn it on. Speaking of the office--they are only there during office hours. My kids locked themselves out of their room at 8am and we had to wait for someone to get there to let them back in.There are many restaurants nearby so the lack of one on the property was a non issue. We did go to The Bowery for a glass of wine one night and were not exactly warmly welcomed by the host in the lobby (I guess we are not hipster enough) until we mentioned that were staying at Lafayette House. If you are looking for a more low key, local NYC experience Lafayette House is definitely the place for an amazing trip.

Sep 28 2009 	Good deal in midtown Manhattan	It's practically impossible to find a decent hotel in midtown Manhattan for under $200/night, but I kept checking until I ran across the La Quinta on West 32nd Street and jumped on it. The location absolutely can't be beat--less than a block from the Herald Square subway station between Broadway and Fifth Avenue, only a few blocks from Times Square and almost directly behind the Empire State Building, and only a couple of blocks from Penn Station. The room was small, as are most NYC hotel rooms, but the bed was comfortable and the bathroom and shower were very good. A couple of nitpicks--it's VERY easy to walk past this place; unlike other hotels in the area there's no banner sign, only smallish plaques on the facade. The elevators are pretty slow, but I was on the second floor and mostly used the stairs. The outlets on the desk didn't work but I'm used to using my laptop on the bed so that was no big deal. The free internet worked fine until the last full day of my stay, Sunday, when it was down all day. Fortunately someone in the area had an open connection so I hooked up on that. If you like Korean food you're in luck, as the hotel is on "Korea Way" and is literally surrounded by 24-hour Korean BBQs. If you don't there's a small deli called Speedy's down the block that makes good sandwiches and hot food, and the usual fast food suspects plus some Irish pubs are very close by. For being so close by hot spots the room was pretty quiet. If you're by yourself or with someone with whom you don't mind sharing close quarters you're probably not going to do better than the La Quinta if you want to stay in midtown--I'll definitely keep this place in mind next time I come to NYC.

Jul 31 2009 	Great rates and as you would expect not perfect	This is a bargain-priced hotel in the shadows of the Empire State Building, near Broadway on 32nd Street, in the Korean neighborhood of Manhattan. It is part of the Apple Core Hotels group, which prides itself on satisfactory accomodations without the traditional high New York prices. Staff is friendly enough, and I felt secure and for the most-part comfortable. My AARP rate of a little over $125 per night USD included high-speed internet and continental breakfast, plus business and fitness centers in the basement, and my small room with a king-size bed overlooking 32nd Street. Those are the "pros." The first "con" is that my room seemed -- even allowing this was New York -- noisy. The trash trucks come along 32nd Street in the 1 - to- 3 a.m. time frame and take a very, very long time to collect huge numbers of sacks of trash from all the Korean restaurants from the previous day. This isn't any quick trash-collection run like "back home," it is a very loud, slow, institutional one. Other "cons" included (1) that the housekeeper didn't come by to clean my room when she said she would (I had adjusted my schedule to accomodate that, all for naught); (2) parts of the room looked worn and in need of spruce-up, but in the hotel's defense there are signs everywhere that new furniture is in the process of being installed; (3) elevator service can be crowded and slow; (4) if you make a reservation through LaQuinta's computer system, be aware that the "Returns" (frequent guest) ID number may not make it onto your record in the hotel's different computer system -- I had to make a couple phone calls after I got home before I got my points. Obviously, none of those "cons," with the possible exception of the noise, will in themselves ruin a stay, so if you can accept them in return for bargain New York rates, I will recommend. Just don't expect luxury -- you aren't paying for it and you won't get it.

I am not an overly large female, so I can't imagine how a large man or any overweight person would fare. Other than that, I was pleased with the room. Didn't partake in the continental breakfast, so I can't comment on that, but we did check out the rooftop bar, which was very busy on a Saturday night. The view of the Empire State Building is indeed great, but if you don't like cigarette smoke this might not be the place for you, since smoking was allowed and, at least that night, was very heavy. Elevators are small/ slow, stairs are not in a creepy/ dirty staircase ,they are a good option.U can easily walk to many places in NYC from here, area was safe. If u have a group and u r not going far, cabs can be a better deal since 4 ride for the price of 1. Penn Station/MSG, 2 blocks away. Catch Amtrak/ Long Island RR here. To get to JFK, take LIRR to Jamaica station (25 mins) transfer to AIRTRAIN . Total cost is about $10,on off peak hrs. Even if u have bags, this is fairly easy. Join the rewards program, it's free. U can redeem points 4 future stays at other LQ hotels. U can easily pay 2x as much and get less elsewhere. I don't think u will get your own bathroom and a good breakfast and many other extras in a great, safe location ,w a great staff for this price anywhere else in mid town.

Nov 1 2008	Another Great Stay	We have just arrived home having stayed in this hotel for 4 nights. This is our 4th year in a row staying in this hotel. As a group of girls on a weekend shopping trip it fits the bill perfectly. We have stayed in many different rooms over the years and each time have found them sufficient for our needs. Having stayed in two other hotels locally the rooms in manhattan for this price are generally small but the rooms at La Quinta are well equiped and clean. The staff at reception are always polite and helpful and on one occassion when my mobile phone charger didnt work they searched until they found me one that was compatible to my phone for me to use for the duration of my stay.This year on our annual visit when we arrived the room we were given only had one bed and was very small. When we returned to reception to explain that we had booked a room with two beds we were told that there had been a problem with the online booking system but it was since sorted. We had booked the room through a website rather than with the hotel directly which we normally do, so perhaps this was partly the problem. The manager on duty that dealt with us was called Victor and was most pleasant and professional. He told that there was no other room available that night but they could offer us another room and promptly took us to the 14th floor. The room we were given was what they called the penthouse! Although it still had just one bed they promptly offered to set up another bed for us. The room in New York standards was huge. It had a very large bed with ample space for a second twin bed and a sofa/table and chairs. The bathroom had a large double walk in shower, jacuzzi and double washand basins, although the room is quiet outdated and the drawer units had the knobs missed on two drawers it was perfect for girls who have a lot of suitcases! The downside of this room is that it is located right next door to the bar, which is open till 1am. However as we never planned on being in bed before that hour it didnt effect us in any way. One night we were in the room before the bar closed and it was very noisy so I doubt that you would get any sleep before the 1am closing time, but if you come all the way to New York they why would you want to be in bed early in a city that never sleeps?!Breakfast is included in the price of the room and is again totally acceptable. Throughout our stay Victor enquired as to how we were enjoying our trip and if the room was satisfactory. We were never charged anything extra for the upgrade which was greatly appreciated.We have recommended this hotel to many people who have also stayed and all commented on its cleanliness and location. It is only a short stroll from Penn Station and most importantly Macys! There are also some lovely places to eat nearby to suit all tastes. While the rooms are generally on the small size they are no smaller than other hotels in this location and represent good value for money. Aug 9 2008 	Affordable rate terrible service ideal location	If I could give this place zero stars I would. The only thing good about this place is the location.
