The guy at the front desk didn't do anything to accommodate us, neither did the manager.Here's what happened. My friend and I arrived just after midnight Saturday morning. We were guaranteed a late check in so we figured we'd have no problem upon arrival. Haha that's funny. We arrive and they tell us there's a problem with our room so they upgraded us to a bigger room...what they didn't tell us that it had one bed (we clearly said we wanted two beds) and it was next to the bar. Um...first of all, my friend was sick, second of all, we actually wanted to sleep. So we go back downstairs and request another room. The guy up front says no problem. We get to this room and we unlock the door only to find LUGGAGE AND PEOPLE in it already. The TV was blaring and everything. Luckily, there weren't people in there doing things half naked or something that could've been embarrassing. So we go downstairs with our luggage again. The guy tries to fix the situation but this time he puts us in a smoking room that was so tiny, a rollaway couldn't fit in there! This time, we're pretty annoyed, tired, cranky and pissed off. So we go downstairs again in the slow as molasses elevator and explain to the guy we want a comp room because a) they screwed it up so many times b) we didn't technically stay for "Friday" and c) they never really fixed the situation because it was almost two o'clock in the morning by the time we got a decent room. All we got was the runaround from the moment we checked in. We have the guy call his manager because there wasn't one on duty, he tried to find us another room at one of their other Apple Core Hotels because that's what good management does. They usually offer to pay the fee for the night and put you up somewhere else. Not this place. We had the option of a) having them WALK US to another hotel at 2 effin' AM in NYC and taking a small fee off our bill b) finding us another room giving us our regular AAA discount plus $50. We settled for another room with a roll away with the plan b arrangement. They finally got us to our room, but it still wasn't worth the trouble. It made the start of our trip lousy...At least we finally got the room we requested for the rest of our stay because they really would've heard from us again. And trust me, it takes a lot to piss us off. The continental breakfast is OK but nothing special and neither are the rooms. They're overpriced for the "quality." Don't do it unless you're desperate. Aug 3 2008 	Solid Value Unassuming Great Location	OK, it's not fancy, the elevators are slow, the rooms are small, and the lobby feels like a hallway, but for $199. this was a great deal for Manhattan. May 31 2008 	Rude and unacceptable receptionist	General:In the past I stayed at the La Quinta hotel at the Ontario airport in California. There I had the most wonderful stay. I told a friend about it and because of that he stayed at the La Quinta in Santa Rosa New Mexico and had a very pleasant stay as well. Those experiences moved the La Quinta chain clearly up on our lists of hotel-preferences. That's also why I booked the La Quinta again in Manhattan.Accessibility.The hotel is very close to a number of subway stations, which makes it very accessible.Room:I had a room with a queen-size bed. The room was about 5 x 5 meters, which I consider the minimum. I come from Europe where hotel-rooms are often smaller. If this is the minimum for me, then I expect it to be too small for most Americans. The bathroom was 3 x 1.5 meters, which I found too small. The room had one window only and it was situated in a corner of the room. This made the room dark and I find dark rooms unpleasant. I always had to have a lamp on.Gym:The gym had a number of cardio machines. I had hoped for weight-lifting material but those weren't there.Internet:There's wireless Internet in the hotel, but that only worked good enough in the lobby. In the room I would sometimes have normal Internet connection, then it would disappear (while I didn't change a thing), and after a while the connection would be back. That way you can't really work on the Internet. Going to the lobby and work on the Internet there should be an alternative, but there's often a draft because people are constantly going in and out of the lobby. The televisions with the news channels in the lobby disturb you while working on your notebook. If the televisions are off there's guitar music playing constantly, which can be a distraction. It's the same song playing over and over again, which makes the distraction worse. Therefore, going on the Internet in the lobby isn't an opton either.Surroundings:The nearest subway station was at the corner of the block, really close-by, which was very nice. There are lots of Korean good restaurants in the area. If you like shopping (LOL, which I don't :-) ), then Macy's is two blocks away, and Manhattan Mall is one block away.Reception:When I checked in the receptionist was unfriendly. Even though I had paid the total bill for my entire stay of 6 nights in cash at arrival, the receptionist still wouldn't accept an international driver's license as an ID, although it met all the requirements he mentioned. While at reception (!) he actually made me go through my luggage to find my passport, even though I had told him several times that I didn't know where I had put it. Although I travel a lot, this had never ever been an issue before (not even in the La Quintain in Los Angeles). He even had the guts to say that he wasn't obliged to let me into the hotel if I didn't show a passport. When I had half of my suitcase unpacked (in order to search for my passport), he complained about the contents of my suitcase being displayed in public, while it was him in the first place who had demanded me to do so. To be frank, I think that this man should find another job.Housekeeping:The personnell that cleaned my room were clearly different. They were nice and helpful. My compliments to them.Conclusion :Would I go there again? Don't hold your breath for it. The current experience moved the La Quinta OFF my list of hotel-preferences. Before submitting this review I sent it to the La Quinta main office in Irving, Texas in February this year to give them an opportunity to correct the situation, but there was no reply whatsoever.About me:I am a male in his fourties from Europe. I travel several times a year and often to the United States. In 2007 I stayed in least in 8 different hotels. Since the extra luxury of the upscale hotels isn't important to me I try to avoid them.

May 29 2008 	Do Not Recommend	My fianc and I stayed at the La Quinta Manhattan from the 12 - 19 May 08 and were disappointed. The water was shut off on the Saturday afternoon. A sign was posted in the lift saying that we would not have water between 1 and 3 pm We returned to the hotel at around half past 3 to discover that we had no water. We reported this to the front desk and they kept passing the buck saying it would be on in half hour. It was off till around half 10 at night. We couldnt shower, use the bathroom or make a cup of coffee in this time. The staff really didnt care. We were checking out on the Monday morning and asked to speak to the manager at around 9am. We were told he was in the hotel but they didnt know where he was. This went on until half 11 and we had been down 5 times!!!! In the end my fiance was told to go find the manager in his office in the basement?? For our inconvenience we stated that we were not happy paying for Saturday night but were happy to pay for the other nights we had stayed there. He knocked 30 dollars off the total bill which was more of an insult and gave the attitude that he couldnt be bothered to do anymore. We found it appalling that we had an issue we wanted to raise with the manager and we had to chase him instead of him coming to the front desk. He told us to take the matter up with the la Quinta chain which I have done but they have since ignored my emailThe hotel also has a friendly note in the room saying ask about our late checkout which we asked about and considering on average we had paid about $250 per night they were going to charge us $315 to use the room for an extra 4 hours. We didnt take them up on this. On getting our final bill which was minus $30 we noticed that we had been charged 3 different sets of fees and taxes per night. When asked what the Javits convention fee was the receptionist could only tell me that it was a government charge then she later mentioned it was a charge for our keys?? but on researching this cannot find anything to say that this is a compulsory charge. Overall the staff were not in the slightest bit helpful, the manager was rude and incompetent and his lack of management experience turned what would have been a good review into a bad review and we will not be staying at any of these hotels again.

We asked at the desk to be changed and although there were no rooms available that night (it was a very busy holiday period) we were given a much bigger room the next day. We found the people on reception were very friendly.The hotel breakfast room was always busy (again it was the holiday season) but as we were in New York we wanted to go out to experience the Deli breakfast culture, so this was not a problem.The hotel location was fantastic, it was in walking distance to all of the main attractions and only a short walk to the subway.With reference to some of the other hotel guests reviews I would agree that the hotel is in need of a little TLC but from my point of view overall it was a pleasant experience.Good find, I'll be back.

Apr 1 2008	Clean 	My family and I had never visited the Big Apple before this trip. We were skeptical because we heard the rooms at many New York hotels were tiny and dirty, and that the staffs were often rude and unresponsive. We were very pleasantly surprised by the La Quinta in Manhattan. Our room was at least the same size as other hotels in less crowded cities. It was clean and there were 2 queen size beds (which were a must, but almost impossible to find in the city!). Our room was missing the shower curtain upon arrival. I called the desk and they said someone would be up to correct this. I waited about 20 min. and called again. The clerk was apologetic and said someone would be there immediately. And guess what...they were! The breakfast was great every morning. It was so helpful that we didn't have to spend time finding a restaurant for breakfast and waiting for service. There were bagels, cereal, coffee, tea, fruit, donuts, yogurt, etc. which offered something for everyone in our family.Don't get me wrong - if you're looking for and can afford the Waldorf-Astoria- you may not want to stay here. We also didn't pay $400 - $500 per night either. If you want a reasonable price for a clean, well-maintained, pleasantly run hotel, this is the place for you. We were there to sightsee and wanted a clean, safe place to stay. We got more than we expected. Everyone from housekeeping to concierge to the person keeping the breakfast items stocked to the manager was friendly and helpful. Even if my husband and I go back w/o children, we would definitely stay here again!

Mar 26 2008 	Issues with La Quinta Manhattan	I recently stayed at the W. 32nd St La Quinta in NYC, and the Room Number Sign was missing the entire time on the outside in the hallway.......the shower had no thermal control...that is, it varied from scalding to freezing cold often during the course of 1 shower (this is a HAZARDOUS situation in my view for children or the elderly!). It occured every time I showered (early morning, as well as late afternoon). Please get this serviced before someone gets seriously burned! Mar 24 2008 	Great Value!	For anybody thinking of travelling to NYC for a break, this is the place to stay. Feb 27 2008 	Could be better	I guess from New York standards and prices it was okay. The Continental Breakfast was not too bad, but the front desk staff was not too helpful at times. Good location, but I wouldn't stay there again if I could help it.

Jan 26 2008 	Comfortable stay	Our third trip to NY and our first stay at La Quinta. In the basement area there is also an internet room.A very nice hotel that I will consider again when I return to NYC.

Jan 18 2008 	Second stay at this hotel	Just got back from our visit to New York,stayed at La Quinta W32 street.Stayed here 2 years ago and decided it is an excellent location and very reasonable breakfast included.It cost us $580 including taxes for 4 nights in a room with two queen beds !Only one tiny problem check in was a bit slow due to the fact the computer system was down.Staff were very courteous room was cleaned daily and towels plentiful.Suggest if travelling from Newark come by rail,$15 single trip comes into Penn Station and two block walk to hotel.We also took trips on the Metro at $2 per trip, one to Coney Island which took about 40 mins.Bubba Gumps on Times Square is a great place to eat,also try the food hall in Grand Central station.Brilliant holiday cant wait to go again.

Jan 16 2008	A Nice Experience	I just came back from a 13 day vacation with my daughter in New York. La Quinta Hotel in Manhattan was a very good choice. Jan 3 2008 	Great value and location	We have stayed two times at the La Quinta since our daughter lives nearby. The location is ideal and the price is right. Jan 2 2008	Happy Customer	I booked this hotel for my fiance's mother between Christmas and New Years. After reading some very negative reviews on this site I started second guessing my choice, but in the end it turned out well. The room was exactly what it should have been for the rating and price. It was clean, comfortable and affordable. An unexpected perk was the generous breakfast. At check-in she did overhear some guests complaining about hot water issues at the front desk, but the staff seemed to be addressing them. We later figured out that shower is labeled backwards, so the hot comes out when it is set on cold. Don't be mislead - all NYC hotel rooms are generally small. If you want luxury you have to pay top dollar. I'm sure La Quinta's in other places where real estate isn't so precious are a lot more spacious. As someone who has lived in NYC - the Herald Sq location is excellent for shopping and exploring the city, with the subway just half a block from the hotel entrance. 32nd Street where the hotel is located is known as Koreatown by New Yorkers, but it's hardly the only thing the area has to offer. Macy's, Madison Sq Garden, Penn Station and the Empire State are all very very short walks. My future mother-in-law was very pleased and plans to go back. This hotel is good value for the price.

Dec 31 2007	La Quinta New Years in NY	Very good location to everything. We were in walking distance to Times Square and Rockafeller Center. Dec 26 2007 	Great location and Price	What a location!!!! If you are debating the Waldorf or this hotel then it's not a fair comparison....the Waldorf bathrooms are gross :). I believe this website is a great tool for travelers. I know I use it ALL the time!

Nov 4 2007 	our stay at la quinta was fine	As visitors to New York from Ireland we had no problems with our stay in La Quinta Manhattanwe got a double room for 2 nights with 2 reservations.one night for $265 the other for $160 .The room was very clean if a little dated,the bathroom was spotless.The breakfast which was included in the price was great,plenty of everything ie cereals,bagels,donuts,yogurts,fruit, even free red bull drinks.The hotel is very central on a very lively street with alot of Korean restaurants, when you leave the hotel turn left for the empire state building a few minutes walk or turn right on leaving hotel for maceys nearby.I would concur with other reviewers that the people on the desk were not very friendly,but i had no real problem with this.In summary i would recommend this hotel for its location and its breakfast.

Jan 17 2007	Exceeded My Expectations	Id like to first point out a billing policy at this hotel that might affect other travelers who book multiple rooms. I booked two rooms on-line through the chains website and used my AAA membership in order to receive a discount. The discount amounted to $18 per night per room for two nights, or $72. At check in, I was told I could apply my AAA membership to only one of the two rooms; that the other room would be charged the non-AAA rate. In the next breath, the clerk said she would honor the AAA rate for both rooms if anyone else in our group of four had either an AARP membership or another AAA membership. We came up with a second AAA card and all was fine but beware of this policy if you book more than one room at the discounted AAA/AARP rate.I cant say enough good things about the staff. Every maid, bellman, clerk, server or maintenance person we encountered was polite and accommodating. There was an efficient busyness, but our requests were honored quickly including a toilet repair that was finished no more than 15 minutes after we called the front desk.Our bedroom was clean and so was the bathroom. The bedroom had one queen bed, a writing table, a straight-back work chair, a chest of drawers, cable television and a coffee maker. The room was small, but completely adequate. We requested non-smoking rooms and there was no lingering smell of smoke. The closet was tiny, with about eight wooden hangers, an iron and ironing board. The rooftop bar resembles a backyard or fraternity barbeque and there is an enclosed area for inclement weather. The bar is open from 5 PM until midnight, year round. Its worth a trip for the view of the Empire State Building, even for non-drinkers. A mixed drink was $5.The hotel is located in the middle of 32nd Street between Fifth Avenue and Broadway. Few places in Manhattan could be more convenient or more centrally located. There is a subway entrance on the corner of 32nd & Broadway, and we had no problem getting a taxi. The free continental breakfast served coffee, juices, fruit, cold cereals, oatmeal, bagels, muffins, toast and doughnuts. We stowed three bags, as we arrived six hours prior to check-in, and stowed the same three bags for several hours after we checked out. There are two elevators which were neither particularly fast nor slow.Our bill at check out was exactly what we had been told it would be, with no hidden charges. There are four separate taxes in Manhattan on hotel rooms; two are percentage taxes, one is a flat $2 per night tax and the other one is a flat $1.50 per night tax that taken together added a fraction under 16.5% to our room rate.The hotel is in a block filled with Korean restaurants and businesses. Odd for Manhattan, there was no delicatessen on the street but we located one around the corner on W. 33rd Street with the usual deli fare and a breakfast special of a bacon, egg & cheese sandwich and coffee for $2.We are budget tourists and this hotel was perfect for us.

There is also a small Korean Market a few doors down that you can purchase snacks and water at a reasonable price. - Staff was nice -- the latino maid was helpful and kept our room clean. Also, the staff at the breakfast was very good at keeping the place fairly clean and choices stocked. - The continental breakfast was decent and offered toast, bagels, pastries, cold cereal and oatmeal. There was also bananas and apples, and your usual choice of beverage: coffee, tea, orange juice, and a cocoa beverage (which I really liked). Overall, good for a light fare and getting you going in the morning. - Be sure to check out the rooftop bar at night, which has an excellent view of the Empire State building! We hung out there a couple of times because the view was so spectacular. The bartender was friendly, and the music was great. Negative:-Room was really SMALL. We stayed in an -02 room, and asked for an alternative room, but were told the hotel was booked. Be sure to ask for a larger room - or ask if you can see the room before you sign for it. It will be worth it, even if you have to wait for the room to be ready. The room was also very musty and smelled. I had to was all our travel clothes again because the smell came home with us in our suitcases. One plus was the bathroom, the shower had good pressure, and there was hot water all the time. - The rooms did not look like the room pictured on their website. I think the photo on their site was a suite. When we were at the rooftop bar, we could peek into the window of a neighboring room and saw it looked like the photo. But our room did not resemble it one bit.- I read in an earlier review that someone else had a problem with their room key. We had the same problem, and had to get our keys changed three times because it did not work. The front desk could not explain why. - The elevators were SLOW, I mean really SLOW! There are only 2 elevators to service everyone in the hotel. We took the stairs a couple of times because it was faster.- Our room did not come with wireless accessibility. I would recommend this hotel for anyone who spends little time in their room and wants a hotel to rest their head at night. There are no frills here. The location and value was good, though I would probably spend more $ and try another hotel next time.

Sep 30 2006 	Not the Ritz but acceptable	I almost cancelled my reservation because of some of the guest comments I read but I'm glad I didnt. My one complaint which I had to endure for the entire stay was no shower curtain in bathroom (despite reporting it) and a bathroom door that doesnt close.Overall I'm a Ritz Carlton guest but for my last minute, had-to-stay in Manhattan trip, the La Quinta Manhattan worked out ok.

Today is Saturday, and the only thing I could do was to block my credit card from further charges. Aug 2 2006 	Jury's still out on this one!	Let's start with the favorable things. Location...half a block from the Empire State Building, subway is close, Manhattan Mall is a block away. When I checked in I was quoted a higher price because I didn't have my AAA card with me...it was circling the block until we could find a place to pull over and unload! I was told the reservation didn't request a non-smoking room (even tho I had my confirmation specifying non-smoking) and that they had no non-smoking rooms available. We tried calling around to change hotels but everything was booked. We were stuck in this smelly, icky room! After spending $15 on room freshners and Febreeze, it still smelled terrible. We suffered through the night. We were up and out early to escape the smell. The second night they did give us a much better and bigger non-smoking double room. The elevators were very slow and sluggish. The overall condition of this property is dingy, and unkempt. Jul 26 2006 	If a business traveler...look elsewhere	La Quintas are usually nice but this one....not so good.I stayed at the La Quinta in Manhattan for a week in July 2006. Jul 26 2006 	Nice Hotel	Myself and my husband stayed here in late June 2005 as a trip of a lifetime before the birth of our first childin NovemberWe checked out the reviews of lots of hotels and despite some bad reviews on here, decided to go with La Quinta as it was relatively cheap.We were not disapointed with our choice at all.The location is fantastic, subway at the end of the block, plenty of cabs going past and right near the empire state building.The room was fine, nothing fancy but when you are getting a cheap rate what can you expect? Jul 21 2006	$139 a nite??	I am coming to NYC in 2 weeks and am getting a rate of $139 a nite at the La Quinta!! Jun 28 2006	Great Value - No complaints from me.	Great location with the subway only a half block away. Desk service was very helpful. Rooms showed some signs of aging and could use sprucing up. Jun 2 2006	OK - But not much more	The location of the La Quinta is very good - just a few steps from Herald Square. The rooms are well maintained though small, which is to be expected in New York. May 23 2006	Great Stay	The La Quinta Manhattan is great value for money, We stayed there for 4 nights. May 22 2006	Review of La Quinta Manhattan	My husband and I stayed here April 19th through 25th. Positives about the hotel: The price was reasonable, and the hotel was convenient to public transportation. There was a "free" continental breakfast available from 7am to 10am, and there was free baggage storage. The room and public areas were kept neat and tidy. The concierge was helpful. The person who cleaned the lunchroom was industrious. The desk clerks answered a lot of questions for us.My main concern was a feeling that there wasn't enough security. There didn't seem to be anyone whose job it was to keep non-guests off the guest floors or out of the breakfast area. When we returned during the day we usually found advertising leaflets shoved under the door of our room. To me this indicated that the street touts had the run of the hallways. The elevators that gave public access to the bar on the roof also stopped at all the other floors. I started to notice that while most of the hotels on the block seemed to have quite visible doormen we would come back to our hotel sometimes and there was no one outside or in the lobby except the desk clerks, who were stationed way off to the side. The concierge, when he was there, seemed to double as a doorman. I several times saw folks at the "free breakfast" who were filling plates full of food that they took with them. Again, like the elevators, there didn't seem to be a system in place to keep non-guests out of the breakfast area, which was off of the lobby. While there may have been surveillance cameras I would have felt safer seeing signs of security.I know that my attitude towards this hotel and to New York in general is shaded because my camera was lost or stolen between this hotel and the hotel room in the next hotel when we checked out. The last time I remember seeing my camera was in my hotel room, but I usually carried it zipped inside my purse. When we got to the next hotel I saw that my purse was unzipped and I didn't have my camera*. In searching for the camera I found that you always need to write down the medallion number of the cab you take just in case you do forget something. There is no central clearing house for "lost and found" either through the police or the taxi company.*Currently, my theory is that my camera was shaken out of my bag in the taxi I took on the way to the next hotel. When I checked Craigslist 'lost and found New York' I saw there were lots of people who report losing their valuables on taxis. Perhaps it is because when you reach your destination safely you are too busy kissing the ground to worry about your belongings? I also wonder if the taxi drivers dodge and swerve deliberately to shake stuff off their passengers?

May 22 2006	Good budget hotel	My wife and I stayed 1 night in May 2006. I reserved the room on La Quinta Inn's web site. We had a very clean, spacious (by ny standards) room with an adequate bathroom. The mattress was a little old but we slept without difficulty. We were on the 5th floor facing 32nd street but found the double paned windows shut out all sounds but the garbage collection at 11:00 pm which lasted only a couple of minutes. There were no hitches in check-in or check-out. The room, with AAA discount, was $187.00 taxes included. The location is a little seedy but we did not feel any apprehension on the street at night. The staff were very pleasant and helpful in giving us directions to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. We heartily recommend this attraction. The number 2 or number 3 subway will take you to the entrance. We will stay at La Quinta Inn on our next visit to Gotham.

Seems like they were encountering a communications breakdown with LaQuinta[-] Finally, the (minimally) English-speaking desk clerk handed me a key to my 5th floor room.The typical NYC small room featured:-windows that would not open (and a view of an old brick wall)-noisy window A/C unit that never cooled the stuffy room-a desk too tiny for anyone to work at-scuzzy old green carpeting (suspect for my sneezing & allergy outbreak)-cheap, thin towelsThe hotel had two slow elevators and a basement fitness room that smelled of sewage. (There was an odd smell throughout the hotel ... like an unemptied grease trap.) I wasn't brave enough to try the breakfast room. (Starbucks and other options a couple blocks away on 5th Avenue.)There was a crowded rooftop bar which was nice for good weather evenings. May 7 2006	Think twice before staying here!!	I booked a queen non-smoking at the La Quinta website for the AAA rate. At check out, I told the front desk clerk that I booked a room with a queen bed, and she immediately responded that they had nothing smaller than queen beds in their hotel, but that some queen beds LOOK like double beds (note I hadn't said anything about a full bed to her at this point). Apr 25 2006	Perfectly fine.	The La Quinta Manhattan is great as far as hotels go. It has a decent bed, a clean bathroom, good temperature control and a TV. Yes, the rooms are tiny but that's to be expected in New York City. The location is great; you're right next to the subway, great shopping and some awesome nightlife. If you are going to New York to walk around the city and not around your room, then this hotel is perfectly fine.

Apr 19 2006	Not bad at all	For NYC prices, the La Quinta was fairly inexpensive but offered a lot more than others in the same price range. It's central location couldn't be beat, as it's near to Penn Station and a couple subway lines, tons of food options, and great shopping. Very safe but busy night and day.I had a room on the 8th floor facing the street. Could be loud at times, but with earplugs I slept great. The room was clean, on the smaller side perhaps, but sufficient for 2 people. Apr 9 2006	good and bad things about it...	I recently stayed at the hotel and upon arrival, I thought it seemed like a great deal for the money. Apr 6 2006	Exceeded Expectations	I lived in NYC for 21 years, so coming back and staying in a hotel was odd, but this place was a perfect choice. Our room was quite large by NYC standards, and it faced the back of the hotel so we had no street noise at all. Room was clean, well maintained, housekeeping did a nice job each day. The continental breakfast more than adequate (cereal, oatmeal, toast, bagels, donuts, juice, coffee, fresh fruit), fresh and constantly replenished.The location is also ideal: 2 blocks from Penn Station, so if you're coming by train, or taking the NJ transit train in from Newark airport, you don't need a cab. The subway was right around the corner, Empire State Building & Macy's less than 2 blocks away. You can walk or take the subway 1 stop to Times Square, to Grand Central, basically to anywhere. The rooftop bar is very pretty and very quiet. The street is the heart of Korean restaurants, many open 24 hours, so it's very safe and you can get something to eat whenever. We had wireless internet access in our room, and in the basement is a business center with 3 working computers connected to the internet, as well as a printer so we could print out our return boarding passes. There's also a small gym that wasn't listed on the hotel website: 2 treadmills, a stair machine and a lifecycle.We did hear some guests complaining about the cost of parking. That's unfortunately normal for NYC, and even if you parked much farther away you really wouldn't get a much cheaper deal for 24 hours. And the 2 elevators are small, and relatively slow - not unexpected for an older building such as this.The baggage room was a big convenience, as we weren't leaving the city until 5 pm so we were able to lock up our bags and go enjoy the day.My ONLY complaint: I searched multiple websites to find the best price, and found out that other people had somehow gotten their rooms for even LESS than we paid. Not really the hotel's fault.All in all, I highly recommend this place, and will probably stay there again.

Apr 6 2006	Good value and clean	Stayed at La Qunita April 1-4 and found it met our expectations based on other reviews. Queen room was on the small side but the bath was almost as large. Clean and quiet, it met our needs nicely. Roof top bar is worth a visit for the view. Tips: wear comfortable walking shoes .. we did six miles on Sunday without trying!! MOMA was great.

Apr 1 2006	The La Quinta was clean well-maintained and a great value	We stayed at the La Quinta Manhattan October 2  9, 2005, and felt it was a great value for the money. Mar 25 2006	Great Location!	I just got back from a 3 night stay at this hotel with a school group and would recommend it. Mar 23 2006	Gave our rooms away	We had booked two rooms at the beginning of the year for 5 nights from the 16th March 2006. Mar 2 2006	Great location and great deal!!	We just stayed at this hotel last week Wed. through Sat. and we really thought it was in a great location. Feb 14 2006	Perfect for a City Break	We stayed in the La Quinta Hotel in January 2006 for a 3 day break to New York.Quite frankly, for a budget hotel in a great location you can't get much better than this.The rooms were a fair size and very clean, the location was excellent - just around the corner from the Empire State Building and within walking distance of Fifth Avenue, Broadway, Times Square. Feb 11 2006	Loved the hotel and location	after reading some reviews about La Quinta Manhattan I wondered had we better change our booking.Glad we didnt,it was excellent!Check in went really well,we were given two queen beds,the staff were very courteous and friendly.We were on the tenth floor,just across from elevator,some noise was experienced but that happens in lots of hotels.We were pleasantly surprised at the space we had(again after reading some critics)closet space was small but what the heck.The hotel bar with its view of Empire State Building was a bonus.Breakfast was ok,you could eat your fill as everything was replenished as quickly as it was used.It was certainly up to our expectations and we will return later in the year if possible.We stayed there 27-31January 2006.

Jan 18 2006	Perfect Location and Great Price	This hotel has a perfect location and is very clean. Check in was a breeze and staff courteous and very helpful. Roof top bar was enjoyable, indoor/outdoor seating you can enjoy gazing at the Empire State Building next door. Macy's and Daffy's are just around the corner as is the subway. Cabs are always passing by and easy to flag down. Room was decorated nice and most importantly as two females we felt safe and the room was very clean. Would select again for future trips. Free continental breakfast.

Jan 10 2006	Honest Deal for the Money	My husband and I stayed there on January 4th and 5th of 2006. We were not totally convinced with the reviews we had read previously but we decided to give it a shot anyway since we got a special promotional fare through Expedia. The people at the lobby were very friendly and available 24 hours. There was also a place by the entrance where we could store our luggage. This was really convenient, especially the day we left because after checking out at noon, our bus wasn't before 9pm and we got the chance to leave it there the whole day at no extra cost. The employees in charge of that locker were also very nice and it was a good thing we were able to take in or out our bags at anytime in the day.Concerning the room, we were a bit disappointed by the one we got on our first night. Everything was clean, but it was just so tiny we barely could walk around the bed. We had quite a few pieces of luggage as well and had to store it all in the little compartment of the room where was the ironing board. We actually were supposed to stay at La Quinta only one night but decided to stay one more to enjoy more of NYC. I had told the people at the lobby in the morning after our first night and we were expecting the room to be done by the maid when we came back at night. However, this was not the case and the people at the reception told me for some reason the message didn't go through! I was surprised when the guy at the lobby told us he could have somebody bring us new sheets and towels! That would have meant that we should have done our room ourselves! I simply told him I didn't agree and he kindly accepted to change us to the room right next to our first room. The fact our first room wasn't done actually made our day. The second room was much bigger. It was as nice and clean as the first one but we really had more space, especially the bathroom which was about twice the size as in the other room.Finally we found convenient the free internet access downstairs and the breakfast was pretty good as well, enough to get us going until lunch. You only have to wake up early cause they no longer serve it after 10 am.All in all, we would definitely go back to La Quinta on another stay in the City.

Jan 5 2006	We're going back!	having read some of the reviews here today, I just can't believe my eyes. We stayed here for St. Patricks Week in March and we're defintely going to stay here again when we visit the states this year. Initially, we were put in a very small room that backed onto what sounded like generators but after we complained following a sleepless night, we were accomodated in a much larger, front facing room with lots of space. I can't speak for the breakfast, we never got up in time, jetlag! but i found 2 good delis at each end of the street that served our needs very adequately and a really gorgeous Italian Restaurant about 2 blocks down that we hope to find again. It's not the ritz, but for 120 dollars a night, it was worth every penny!

Dec 14 2005	EXCELLENT	This was a great choice. You certainly were not pampered, but you had everything you needed. Clean, with instant hot water, good breakfast in the morning. Nov 22 2005	Even Girlfriend Thought it was Fine.	The girlfriend and I stayed here in late August and found the hotel was just fine. I mention these things because these are some of the complaints that have been lodged against the La Quinta by other Trip Advisor members. (The shuttle was $45 one-way to LaGuardia airport. We used a cab and paid $27 each way, including tip and tolls! Aug 18 2005	At least it was clean!	After reading some of the reviews posted on this website, I was really nervous about staying at this hotel. Aug 10 2005	Don't bother the staff-you're only a guest	my sisters and i stayed at the laquinta hotel in late july, and i doubt i'd ever stay there again. the hotel is a remodeled older hotel and has a very nice front entrance. it is on a street known as little korea. the rooms and rest of the hotel are satisfactory, but the bathroom exhaust fan was so noisy, it was like being on a runway at laguardia. we checked in at 11:00 & went out until 5:00 (check-in is 3:00) and our room still wasn't cleaned upon our return. i specifically asked for enough towels for three, but still had to put in a call to the front desk for a few more. which brings me to the staff-they treat you like you are a minor intrusion to their day. they spoke to guests as little as possible; needless to say, i avoided asking for much. they made an error on my bill, & left a message on the room phone telling me i owed them .50 cents (i didn't). there was a $1.50 per day tax on the bill for the javits center-wasn't sure why, but i was sure i didn't want to ask that staff!

Jun 12 2005	Too many drawbacks	We stayed here June 4 - 9 after reading reviews on tripadvisor. Got a good rate through the applecorehotels reservations site. The weather was hot and sticky the whole time we were in New York and the AC in the room was blowing air, no cooling. We called about this and maintenance came right away and flushed the system, telling us that it would cool down soon. After 30 minutes, there was no change. We called again and asked if we could be moved. The front desk said the hotel was sold out and they would have maintenance check on it again. After another 30 minutes and no maintenance person, we called applecore to see if they could help us (either move us to another property or get us another room). They said they would see what they could do. We left for dinner and talked to the front desk. They assured us they would get it fixed or move us.When we got back the room was frigid! We didn't dare adjust it the rest of the stay. So not a great impression upon arrival. But at least it was cool.The pros: price ($149 per night), breakfast included (well stocked and adequate quality), free wireless connection (easy and fast), location (access to several subway lines within the block and more just one avenue away) and rooftop lounge (right below the Empire State building).The cons: smoking room was more than Fabreze could handle, interior room had awful dark view (couldn't even tell if sun was out), countertop in bathroom was too long and you could not sit on the toilet without leaning to the side (and I'm not fat!), bed comfort and linens were below par (and I know not to expect much), tub was very slippery (we had to put a wash cloth down for traction), and the maid service was spotty (at different times there was no bath mat, no hand towels, no tissues, etc.). May 19 2005	Ok - but showing lack of upkeep	I stayed here for four days in mid-May while on vacation.For some reason, the NY Times Guide to New York (2005) rates this place very highly, so I decided to try it. I've never been to NYC. They gave me a quiet, no-smoking room like I requested. On the 12th floor.The problems...A/C didn't work, it was on full cool but was actually heating the room. It obviously needs some sort of overhaul.Of course, the windows are to be left closed! I called them again and again and they weren't really interested. Eventually they gave me a fan and opened a window. That worked pretty well as it cooled off in the city at night. For the rest of my stay I just left the window open. That may not be an option in the summer! The shower head had been taken apart. When I turned on the shower, water went everywhere. I put the shower head back together. Lots of hot water, great shower.The faucet in the sink doesn't drip, it leaks. If you get it just about half way between open and closed it might stop running (weird).The wireless internet did not work, the signal is too weak. As usual for a large city, I was picking up signals from wireless points in adjacent buildings, which evidently don't have free internet. The wireless doesn't work in the lobby either. The smell comes from the laundry room in the basement, next to the business center. It's that sour milk smell. With no A/C in the basement, it gets humid and then that smell is almost overpowering. The smell drifts up to the lobby, but isn't as strong. Importantly, the smell does not seem to make its way any further up the hotel. If you just come down to the lobby and leave you might never notice it. But if you need to do some work down at the business center, you might want to bring your own oxygen.The other thing I heard - the elevators. Yes, they are small and old and did break down, causing lines of people waiting to get up. But they fixed it quickly. The staff uses the elevators a lot, laundry baskets and equipment are often hogging them (where's the service elevators?). Watch the step when you get off! No problem with breakfast. They man keeps the place stocked while people swarm in and out. Just the basics. Good bagels. Juice machines spray your feet (stand back). They ought to fix that one toaster - if they would just put on a new handle people could use it. If you don't like the free breakfast, you can walk a half block out to 5th or Broadway and get whatever you want, including 3 or 4 fast food places. Lots of places to eat around there. The business center has some old and worn down PC's and "chairs". The internet worked well. A couple times some foreign guests were there surfing porn sites - whatever. It's important to have access to the internet to get tickets and times to events in NY. I downloaded subway schedules and maps.The location is great. It's in "Korea town", really "Korea street". I arrived via train at Penn Station. I just walked the two blocks to the hotel. Madison Square Garden is next to Penn Station, so this might be a good place to stay if you want to take in an event there.Empire State Building is a block and a half. The subway station is at the end of the block at Broadway and 32nd. Several trains run through there. Including the R and W which will take you down to Battery Park/Wall St/WTC site. The W and N will take you to Queens and the bus to LaGuardia. MTA is doing construction on the subway, so you can sometimes not get back to the 34th St station on weekends. You can also pick up those double decker tour bus at the Empire State (for tourists).Overall I had a good vacation. The hotel issues didn't become big ones. What bothers me is that La Quinta doesn't seem at all interested in keeping the place up. A lot of broken little stuff which indicates a lack of interest.NY isn't cheap, but that doesn't mean that can just let the place fall apart and charge less.Compared to other places in NY, it's cheaper and the location is good. But it might be worth spending the extra $ or so a night to get a place that's kept up. Because if you have some problems, they probably won't fix them.I would probably stay somewhere else next time I visit NY.

May 19 2005	Great choice!	La Quinta Inn was a great choice to stay in NY. In general, hotels in NY are expensive and below the European quality standards (unless you are willing to pay a fortune). Considering this, La Quinta Inn was clean, with friendly staff, the price includes breakfast and quite well located. It was a great choice and I had a great time in NY.

May 18 2005	we loved it	lovely clean hotel, excellent value for money in a great location.Free breakfast every morning as well. We filled up on the breakfast and didnt need to eat again till dinner so it saved us money there as well. I would definitely definitely stay here again. thums up!!

May 18 2005	Great Value at an Excellent Location	I recently stayed at the LaQuinta Manhattan based on the reviews at this site and I must say the good comments were on the mark. My room, which was a non-smoking Queen for $99 a night, was clean and spacious. The bathroom was well equipped with a dryer, phone, generous amounts of toiletries, and plenty of hot water for the shower. Best of all, the bed was amazingly comfortable. I didn't have the best view, as my room overlooked the back of another building, but if I looked upward I could easily see the Empire State Building. Then again, I don't come to NYC to lounge in a hotel room so it was no big deal. Excellent location, with Penn Station, the subway, Macy's and the Empire State Building literally a couple of minutes away.For as much as I was pleased with the hotel, I can only give them 4 stars because of the following: I had the air conditioning on at full blast but the room never felt cooler than 75 degrees; and the front desk staff could have been less rushed, though I must give a good word for the bell staff who were helpful and always had smiles. I highly recommend the La Quinta Manhattan and will stay there again.

May 13 2005 	Great value!	I stayed at the La Quinta and was quite impressed with the hotel. I didn't expect to have breakfast included in the rate I paid and also free Wireless Internet throughout the hotel. The free wireless really was fantastic as that was just what I needed as I was in nyc for business- so many larger hotels don't seem to have it. The staff were polite and the room was clean and comfortable. I was very pleasantly surprised and impressed with the hotel's amenities! I shall definitely be back here next time I am in nyc!

May 11 2005	Good value for money	We stayed for five nights in April, this was not our first choice because we booked quite late, and could only have a queen room but this was adequate. We asked for a quiet room, so were at the rear of the hotel and it was quite dark but had a view of the Empire State Building, it was clean and the bed was comfortable. Breakfast good -I liked the bagels, and there was internet access in basement and a gym. The location is very convenient, many places in walking distance and we found the staff helpful. This hotel was very good for the money, although we paid $125 plus more at the weekend, perhaps due to late booking.

May 10 2005	Satisfactory Clean but Marginal Residual feelings	After a number of trips to NYC, I view this hotel as functional and very clean, but with fairly BLAH, mostly due to disinterested or crabby front desk staff. Phone assistance was good, with prompt followup calls when hot water was slow to come. The maid (Gangha) was lovely, the room immaculate, and the breakfast was nice (the breakfast man was friendly too). There is a tiny basement gym.First Impressions being what they are....STAFF DEMEANOR means so much to me, that I view most hotels through that particular looking glass. Plus, I travel alone. Who wants a meany at the front desk?Having asthma, I asked for a Non-Smoking room, but on arrival had to strongly stress that all over again to an eye-rolling, blase' Melinda, who said "I don't understand what it is you want." Duhhhhh---however, to the Hotel's credit, they quickly came up with a room even though I was first told the hotel was full. Actually, my 7th floor hallway was nice and quiet and I did not see anything that looked like a FULL hotel. There was no view, but I kept the curtains drawn and watched the excellent TV with extras--and slept well. I felt secure there.When making arrangements, I asked for an e-mail verification of my non-smoking room reservation and employee SUNIT told me "We don't DO e-mail," hence it arrived via mail while I was in NYC. I think this member of the CORE hotel chain is acceptable, but not a winner I'd seek out again. The location is seedy due to ugly area and garbage and such (in the Korean district). But good things are within easy reach---Times Square, etc. Interestingly, another hotel in the chain (RedRoof) is across the street. I paid $139/nite for 3 nites, $179.00 the 4th.I think the location and value is no more than the $139/nite MAX.I prefer the Milford and its area above this site--even though the Milford rooms are tiny.

May 6 2005	Great Value in Midtown Manhatten	My husband and I celebrated our 20 year anniversary in NYC this year and stayed at this hotel. It is a great location, Macys half a block, 5th Ave half a block, everything very close. Nice sized room, clean, great spread in the morning in the lobby, muffins, coffee, croissants, cereal, fruit, etc... Will definately stay again! We got our room with a king bed for $100 per night!

May 2 2005	Great location.	My friend and I stayed 7 nights, and were very pleased with the hotel.
